arXiv:2410.04887v1 [cs.LG] 07 Oct 2024

Wide Neural Networks Trained with Weight Decay
Provably Exhibit Neural Collapse

Arthur Jacot, ‚Äâ‚Äâ‚ÄâPeter S√∫ken√≠k, ‚Äâ‚Äâ‚ÄâZihan Wang, ‚Äâ‚Äâ‚Äâand Marco Mondelli Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences, NYU. Email: arthur.jacot@nyu.eduInstitute of Science and Technology Austria. Email: peter.sukenik@ista.ac.atCourant Institute of Mathematical Sciences, NYU. Email: zw3508@nyu.eduInstitute of Science and Technology Austria. Email: marco.mondelli@ist.ac.at
Abstract

Deep neural networks (DNNs) at convergence consistently represent the training data in the last layer via a highly symmetric geometric structure referred to as neural collapse. This empirical evidence has spurred a line of theoretical research aimed at proving the emergence of neural collapse, mostly focusing on the unconstrained features model. Here, the features of the penultimate layer are free variables, which makes the model data-agnostic and, hence, puts into question its ability to capture DNN training. Our work addresses the issue, moving away from unconstrained features and studying DNNs that end with at least two linear layers. We first prove generic guarantees on neural collapse that assume (i) low training error and balancedness of the linear layers (for within-class variability collapse), and (ii) bounded conditioning of the features before the linear part (for orthogonality of class-means, as well as their alignment with weight matrices). We then show that such assumptions hold for gradient descent training with weight decay: (i) for networks with a wide first layer, we prove low training error and balancedness, and (ii) for solutions that are either nearly optimal or stable under large learning rates, we additionally prove the bounded conditioning. Taken together, our results are the first to show neural collapse in the end-to-end training of DNNs.

1 Introduction

Among the many possible interpolators that a deep neural network (DNN) can find, Papyan et al. (2020) showed a strong bias of gradient-based training towards representations with a highly symmetric structure in the penultimate layer, which was dubbed neural collapse (NC). In particular, the feature vectors of the training data in the penultimate layer collapse to a single vector per class (NC1); these vectors form orthogonal or simplex equiangular tight frames (NC2), and they are aligned with the last layer‚Äôs row weight vectors (NC3). The question of why and how neural collapse emerges has been considered by a popular line of research, see e.g. Lu & Steinerberger (2022); E & Wojtowytsch (2022) and the discussion in Section 2. Many of these works focus on a simplified mathematical framework: the unconstrained features model (UFM) (Mixon et al., 2020; Han et al., 2022; Zhou et al., 2022a), corresponding to the joint optimization over the last layer‚Äôs weights and the penultimate layer‚Äôs feature representations, which are treated as free variables. To account for the existence of the training data and of all the layers before the penultimate (i.e., the backbone of the network), some form of regularization on the free features is usually added. A number of papers has proved the optimality of NC in this model (Lu & Steinerberger, 2022; E & Wojtowytsch, 2022), its emergence with gradient-based methods (Mixon et al., 2020; Han et al., 2022) and a benign loss landscape (Zhou et al., 2022a; Zhu et al., 2021). However, the major drawback of the UFM lies in its data-agnostic nature: it only acknowledges the presence of training data and backbone through a simple form of regularization (e.g., Frobenius norm or sphere constraint), which is far from being equivalent to end-to-end training. Moving beyond UFM, existing results are either only applicable to rather shallow networks (of at most three layers) (Kothapalli & Tirer, 2024; Hong & Ling, 2024) or hold under strong assumptions, such as symmetric quasi-interpolation (Xu et al., 2023; Rangamani & Banburski-Fahey, 2022), block-structured empirical NTK throughout training (Seleznova et al., 2023), or geodesic structure of the features across all layers (Wang et al., 2024).

In this paper, we provide the first end-to-end proof of within-class variability collapse (NC1) for a class of networks that end with at least two linear layers. Furthermore, we give rather weak sufficient conditions ‚Äì either near-optimality or stability under large learning rates ‚Äì for solutions to exhibit the orthogonality of class-means (NC2) and the alignment of class means with the last weight matrix (NC3). More precisely, our contributions can be summarized as follows:

  • ‚Ä¢

    First, we show that within-class variability collapse (i.e., NC1) occurs, as long as the training error is low and the linear layers are approximately balanced, i.e., ‚ÄñW‚Ñì+1T‚Å¢W‚Ñì+1‚àíW‚Ñì‚Å¢W‚ÑìT‚ÄñFsubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptùëä‚Ñì1ùëásubscriptùëä‚Ñì1subscriptùëä‚Ñìsuperscriptsubscriptùëä‚Ñìùëáùêπ\left\|W_{\ell+1}^{T}W_{\ell+1}-W_{\ell}W_{\ell}^{T}\right\|_{F}‚à• italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is small, where W‚Ñì+1,W‚Ñìsubscriptùëä‚Ñì1subscriptùëä‚ÑìW_{\ell+1},W_{\ell}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are two consecutive weight matrices of the linear head. If, additionally, the conditioning of the linear head mapping is bounded, we bound the conditioning of the matrix of class means in the last layer, as well as that of the last weight matrix. This implies that, as the number of linear layers grows, class means become orthogonal and, furthermore, they align with the last layer‚Äôs row vectors, which proves both NC2 and NC3.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Next, we show that the sufficient conditions above for NC1 are satisfied by a class of deep networks with a wide first layer, smooth activations and pyramidal topology, after gradient training with weight decay. This provides the first guarantee of the emergence of NC1 for a deep network trained end-to-end via gradient descent.

  • ‚Ä¢

    We further present two sufficient conditions under which the linear head is guaranteed to be well-conditioned, hence NC1, NC2 and NC3 hold: either the network approaches a global optimum of the ‚Ñì2subscript‚Ñì2\ell_{2}roman_‚Ñì start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-regularized square loss, or it nearly interpolates the data while being stable under large learning rates.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Our numerical experiments on various architectures (fully connected, ResNet) and datasets (MNIST, CIFAR) confirm the insights coming from the theory: (i) NC2 is more prominent as the depth of the linear head increases, and (ii) the final linear layers are balanced at convergence. Furthermore, we show that, as the non-linear part of the network gets deeper, the non-negative layers become less non-linear and more balanced.

2 Related Work

Neural collapse.

Since its introduction by Papyan et al. (2020), neural collapse has been intensively studied, both from a theoretical and practical viewpoint. Practitioners use the NC for a number of applications, including transfer learning, OOD detection and generalization bounds (Galanti et al., 2022a; Haas et al., 2022; Ben-Shaul & Dekel, 2022; Li et al., 2023a, b; Zhang et al., 2024). On the theoretical front, the most widely adopted framework to study the emergence of NC is the unconstrained features model (UFM) (Mixon et al., 2020; Fang et al., 2021). Under the UFM, the NC has been proved to be optimal with cross-entropy loss (E & Wojtowytsch, 2022; Lu & Steinerberger, 2022; Kunin et al., 2022), MSE loss (Zhou et al., 2022a) and other losses (Zhou et al., 2022b). Optimality guarantees for the generalization of NC to the class-imbalanced setting have been provided by Fang et al. (2021); Thrampoulidis et al. (2022); Hong & Ling (2023); Dang et al. (2024). Besides global optimality, a benign loss landscape around NC solutions has been proved in Zhu et al. (2021); Ji et al. (2022); Zhou et al. (2022a), and the emergence of NC with gradient-based optimization under UFM has been studied by Mixon et al. (2020); Han et al. (2022); Ji et al. (2022); Wang et al. (2022). Jiang et al. (2023) extend the analysis to large number of classes, Kothapalli et al. (2023) to graph neural networks, Tirer et al. (2023) generalize UFM with a perturbation to account for its imperfections, while Andriopoulos et al. (2024) generalize UFM and NC to regression problems. A deep neural collapse is theoretically analyzed with deep UFM for the linear case in Dang et al. (2023); Garrod & Keating (2024), for the non-linear case with two layers in Tirer & Bruna (2022), and for the deep non-linear case in S√∫ken√≠k et al. (2023, 2024), where, notably, the latter work provides the first negative result on deep NC with deep UFM.

A line of recent work aims at circumventing the data-agnostic nature of UFM, showing the emergence of neural collapse in settings closer to practice. Specifically, Seleznova et al. (2023) assume a block structure in the empirical NTK matrix. Kernels are used by Kothapalli & Tirer (2024) to analyze NC in wide two-layer networks, showing mostly negative results in the NTK regime. Beaglehole et al. (2024) prove the emergence of deep neural collapse using kernel-based layer-wise training, and they show that NC is an optimal solution of adaptive kernel ridge regression in an over-parametrized regime. Sufficient (but rather strong) conditions for the emergence of NC beyond UFM are provided by Pan & Cao (2023). Hong & Ling (2024) analyze two and three layer networks end-to-end, but only provide conditions under which the UFM optimal solutions are feasible. Wang et al. (2024) consider the NC formation in residual networks, and the model is similar to the perturbed UFM in Tirer et al. (2023). However, the results crucially assume that the features lie on a geodesic in euclidean space, and proving that this is the case after training the ResNet is an open problem. Rangamani & Banburski-Fahey (2022); Xu et al. (2023) focus on homogeneous networks trained via gradient-based methods, making the strong assumption of symmetric quasi-interpolation. Then, Rangamani & Banburski-Fahey (2022) do not prove this assumption, and the argument of Xu et al. (2023) requires a regularization different from the one used in practice as well as interpolators with a given norm (whose existence is an open question). We also note that the quasi-interpolation property does not hold in practice exactly, which points to the need of a perturbation analysis.

Implicit bias.

Our approach leverages the (approximate) balancedness of the weights, which plays a central role in the analysis of the training dynamics of linear networks (Arora et al., 2018b) and leads to a bias towards low-rank matrices (Arora et al., 2019; Tu et al., 2024). In the presence of weight decay, the low-rank bias can be made even more explicit (Dai et al., 2021), and it is reinforced by stochastic gradient descent (Wang & Jacot, 2024). Moving towards nonlinear models, shallow networks with weight decay exhibit low-rank bias, as described by the variational norm (Bach, 2017), or Barron norm (E et al., 2019), and this bias provably emerges under (modified) GD dynamics (Abbe et al., 2022; Bietti et al., 2022; Lee et al., 2024). However, a single hidden layer appears to be insufficient to exhibit NC for most datasets. Moving towards deep nonlinear models, networks with weight decay are also known to exhibit low-rank bias (Galanti et al., 2022b; Jacot et al., 2022), which can be related to neural collapse (Zangrando et al., 2024). The dimensionality and rank of the weights/representations varies between layers, exhibiting a bottleneck structure (Jacot, 2023a, b; Wen & Jacot, 2024). We remark that existing results apply to the global minima of the ‚Ñì2subscript‚Ñì2\ell_{2}roman_‚Ñì start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-regularized loss. In contrast, our paper provides rather general sufficient conditions that are then provably satisfied by GD, thus showing that the training algorithm is responsible for neural collapse.

3 Balancedness and Interpolation Imply Neural Collapse

Notation and problem setup.

Given a matrix Aùê¥Aitalic_A of rank kùëòkitalic_k, we denote by Ai:subscriptùê¥:ùëñabsentA_{i:}italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i : end_POSTSUBSCRIPT its iùëñiitalic_i-th row, by A:isubscriptùê¥:absentùëñA_{:i}italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT : italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT its iùëñiitalic_i-th column, by s1‚Å¢(A)‚â•‚ãØ‚â•sk‚Å¢(A)subscriptùë†1ùê¥‚ãØsubscriptùë†ùëòùê¥s_{1}(A)\geq\cdots\geq s_{k}(A)italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_A ) ‚â• ‚ãØ ‚â• italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_A ) its singular values in non-increasing order, and by Œ∫‚Å¢(A)ùúÖùê¥\kappa(A)italic_Œ∫ ( italic_A ) the ratio s1‚Å¢(A)sk‚Å¢(A)subscriptùë†1ùê¥subscriptùë†ùëòùê¥\frac{s_{1}(A)}{s_{k}(A)}divide start_ARG italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_A ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_A ) end_ARG between its largest and smallest non-zero singular values. where the activation function œÉùúé\sigmaitalic_œÉ is applied componentwise and, given an integer nùëõnitalic_n, we use the shorthand [n]:={1,‚Ä¶,n}assigndelimited-[]ùëõ1‚Ä¶ùëõ[n]:=\{1,\ldots,n\}[ italic_n ] := { 1 , ‚Ä¶ , italic_n }. We write Œ∏ùúÉ\thetaitalic_Œ∏ for the vector obtained by concatenating all parameters {Wi}i‚àà[L]subscriptsubscriptùëäùëñùëñdelimited-[]ùêø\{W_{i}\}_{i\in[L]}{ italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ‚àà [ italic_L ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Wm:‚Ñìsubscriptùëä:ùëö‚ÑìW_{m:\ell}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m : roman_‚Ñì end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for the partial products of the weight matrices Wm‚Å¢‚ãØ‚Å¢W‚Ñìsubscriptùëäùëö‚ãØsubscriptùëä‚ÑìW_{m}\cdots W_{\ell}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ãØ italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, so that Zm=Wm:‚Ñì+1‚Å¢Z‚Ñìsubscriptùëçùëösubscriptùëä:ùëö‚Ñì1subscriptùëç‚ÑìZ_{m}=W_{m:\ell+1}Z_{\ell}italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m : roman_‚Ñì + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for all m‚â•‚Ñì‚àà{L1+1,‚Ä¶,L1+L2}ùëö‚Ñìsubscriptùêø11‚Ä¶subscriptùêø1subscriptùêø2m\geq\ell\in\{L_{1}+1,\dots,L_{1}+L_{2}\}italic_m ‚â• roman_‚Ñì ‚àà { italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 , ‚Ä¶ , italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }.

We index individual samples in a feature matrix ZùëçZitalic_Z as zc‚Å¢i,subscriptùëßùëêùëñz_{ci},italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , meaning the iùëñiitalic_i-th sample of the cùëêcitalic_c-th class, sometimes adding an upper-index to denote the layer or matrix to which the sample belongs. Let Œºcsubscriptùúáùëê\mu_{c}italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denote the mean of all samples from class cùëêcitalic_c and ŒºGsubscriptùúáùê∫\mu_{G}italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT the global mean. Let Z¬Ø¬Øùëç\bar{Z}over¬Ø start_ARG italic_Z end_ARG be the matrix of class-means stacked into columns. The NC1 metric on a feature matrix ZùëçZitalic_Z is given by tr‚Å¢(Œ£W)tr‚Å¢(Œ£B),trsubscriptŒ£ùëätrsubscriptŒ£ùêµ\frac{\text{tr}(\Sigma_{W})}{\text{tr}(\Sigma_{B})},divide start_ARG tr ( roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG tr ( roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG , where Œ£W=1N‚Å¢‚àëc,i(zc‚Å¢i‚àíŒºc)‚Å¢(zc‚Å¢i‚àíŒºc)‚ä§subscriptŒ£ùëä1ùëÅsubscriptùëêùëñsubscriptùëßùëêùëñsubscriptùúáùëêsuperscriptsubscriptùëßùëêùëñsubscriptùúáùëêtop\Sigma_{W}=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{c,i}(z_{ci}-\mu_{c})(z_{ci}-\mu_{c})^{\top}roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_N end_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and Œ£B=1K‚Å¢‚àëc=1K(Œºc‚àíŒºG)‚Å¢(Œºc‚àíŒºG)‚ä§.subscriptŒ£ùêµ1ùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùëê1ùêæsubscriptùúáùëêsubscriptùúáùê∫superscriptsubscriptùúáùëêsubscriptùúáùê∫top\Sigma_{B}=\frac{1}{K}\sum_{c=1}^{K}(\mu_{c}-\mu_{G})(\mu_{c}-\mu_{G})^{\top}.roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ( italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . The NC2 metric on a feature matrix ZùëçZitalic_Z is defined as Œ∫‚Å¢(Z¬Ø)ùúÖ¬Øùëç\kappa(\bar{Z})italic_Œ∫ ( over¬Ø start_ARG italic_Z end_ARG ), i.e., the conditioning number of the class-mean matrix of Z.ùëçZ.italic_Z . The NC3 metric on a feature matrix ZùëçZitalic_Z and a weight matrix WùëäWitalic_W is defined as 1N‚Å¢‚àëc,icos‚Å°(zc‚Å¢i,Wc:),1ùëÅsubscriptùëêùëñsubscriptùëßùëêùëñsubscriptùëä:ùëêabsent\frac{1}{N}\sum_{c,i}\cos(z_{ci},W_{c:}),divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_N end_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cos ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c : end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , i.e., the average cosine similarity of features and weight vectors corresponding to the features‚Äô class.

At this point, we state our result giving a set of sufficient conditions for NC1, NC2 and NC3.

Theorem 3.1.

If the network satisfies

  • ‚Ä¢

    approximate interpolation, i.e., ‚ÄñZL‚àíY‚ÄñF‚â§œµ1subscriptnormsubscriptùëçùêøùëåùêπsubscriptitalic-œµ1\left\|Z_{L}-Y\right\|_{F}\leq\epsilon_{1}‚à• italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Y ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â§ italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT,

  • ‚Ä¢

    approximate balancedness, i.e., ‚ÄñW‚Ñì+1‚ä§‚Å¢W‚Ñì+1‚àíW‚Ñì‚Å¢W‚Ñì‚ä§‚Äño‚Å¢p‚â§œµ2subscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptùëä‚Ñì1topsubscriptùëä‚Ñì1subscriptùëä‚Ñìsuperscriptsubscriptùëä‚Ñìtopùëúùëùsubscriptitalic-œµ2\left\|W_{\ell+1}^{\top}W_{\ell+1}-W_{\ell}W_{\ell}^{\top}\right\|_{op}\leq% \epsilon_{2}‚à• italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â§ italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, for ‚Ñì‚àà{L1+1,‚Ä¶,L‚àí1}‚Ñìsubscriptùêø11‚Ä¶ùêø1\ell\in\{L_{1}+1,\ldots,L-1\}roman_‚Ñì ‚àà { italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 , ‚Ä¶ , italic_L - 1 },

  • ‚Ä¢

    bounded representations and weights, i.e., ‚ÄñZL‚àí2‚Äño‚Å¢p,‚ÄñZL‚àí1‚Äño‚Å¢p,‚ÄñW‚Ñì‚Äño‚Å¢p‚â§rsubscriptnormsubscriptùëçùêø2ùëúùëùsubscriptnormsubscriptùëçùêø1ùëúùëùsubscriptnormsubscriptùëä‚Ñìùëúùëùùëü\left\|Z_{L-2}\right\|_{op},\left\|Z_{L-1}\right\|_{op},\left\|W_{\ell}\right% \|_{op}\leq r‚à• italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚à• italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚à• italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â§ italic_r, for ‚Ñì‚àà{L1+1,‚Ä¶,L}‚Ñìsubscriptùêø11‚Ä¶ùêø\ell\in\{L_{1}+1,\ldots,L\}roman_‚Ñì ‚àà { italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 , ‚Ä¶ , italic_L },

then if œµ1‚â§min(sK‚Å¢(Y),(K‚àí1)‚Å¢N4‚Å¢K)subscriptitalic-œµ1minsubscriptùë†ùêæùëåùêæ1ùëÅ4ùêæ\epsilon_{1}\leq\mathop{\rm min}\nolimits\left(s_{K}(Y),\sqrt{\frac{(K-1)N}{4K% }}\right)italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â§ roman_min ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Y ) , square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG ( italic_K - 1 ) italic_N end_ARG start_ARG 4 italic_K end_ARG end_ARG ),

with œµ=L222‚Å¢r2‚Å¢(L2‚àí1)‚Å¢œµ2(sK‚Å¢(Y)‚àíœµ1)2‚ÄñX‚Äño‚Å¢p2‚Å¢r2‚Å¢L1‚àíL222‚Å¢r2‚Å¢(L2‚àí1)‚Å¢œµ2italic-œµsuperscriptsubscriptùêø222superscriptùëü2subscriptùêø21subscriptitalic-œµ2superscriptsubscriptùë†ùêæùëåsubscriptitalic-œµ12superscriptsubscriptnormùëãùëúùëù2superscriptùëü2subscriptùêø1superscriptsubscriptùêø222superscriptùëü2subscriptùêø21subscriptitalic-œµ2\epsilon=\frac{\frac{L_{2}^{2}}{2}r^{2(L_{2}-1)}\epsilon_{2}}{\frac{(s_{K}(Y)-% \epsilon_{1})^{2}}{\left\|X\right\|_{op}^{2}r^{2L_{1}}}-\frac{L_{2}^{2}}{2}r^{% 2(L_{2}-1)}\epsilon_{2}}italic_œµ = divide start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 ( italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG divide start_ARG ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Y ) - italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ‚à• italic_X ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG - divide start_ARG italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 ( italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG. Finally,

NC2‚Å¢(ZL‚àí1)NC2subscriptùëçùêø1\displaystyle\text{NC2}(Z_{L-1})NC2 ( italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ‚â§Œ∫‚Å¢(WL)+sK‚Å¢(Y)‚àí1‚Å¢r‚Å¢Œ®‚Å¢(œµ1,œµ2,r)1‚àísK‚Å¢(Y)‚àí1‚Å¢r‚Å¢Œ®‚Å¢(œµ1,œµ2,r)absentùúÖsubscriptùëäùêøsubscriptùë†ùêæsuperscriptùëå1ùëüŒ®subscriptitalic-œµ1subscriptitalic-œµ2ùëü1subscriptùë†ùêæsuperscriptùëå1ùëüŒ®subscriptitalic-œµ1subscriptitalic-œµ2ùëü\displaystyle\leq\frac{\kappa(W_{L})+s_{K}(Y)^{-1}r\Psi(\epsilon_{1},\epsilon_% {2},r)}{1-s_{K}(Y)^{-1}r\Psi(\epsilon_{1},\epsilon_{2},r)}‚â§ divide start_ARG italic_Œ∫ ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Y ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_r roman_Œ® ( italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_r ) end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Y ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_r roman_Œ® ( italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_r ) end_ARG (4)
NC3‚Å¢(ZL‚àí1,WL)NC3subscriptùëçùêø1subscriptùëäùêø\displaystyle\text{NC3}(Z_{L-1},W_{L})NC3 ( italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ‚â•(N‚àíœµ1)2+N‚Å¢(Œ∫‚Å¢(WL))‚àí2‚àí(r‚Å¢Œ®‚Å¢(œµ1,œµ2,r)+K‚Å¢(Œ∫‚Å¢(WL)2‚àí1))22‚Å¢N‚Å¢Œ∫‚Å¢(WL)‚Å¢(1+œµ1).absentsuperscriptùëÅsubscriptitalic-œµ12ùëÅsuperscriptùúÖsubscriptùëäùêø2superscriptùëüŒ®subscriptitalic-œµ1subscriptitalic-œµ2ùëüùêæùúÖsuperscriptsubscriptùëäùêø2122ùëÅùúÖsubscriptùëäùêø1subscriptitalic-œµ1\displaystyle\geq\frac{(\sqrt{N}-\epsilon_{1})^{2}+N(\kappa(W_{L}))^{-2}-\left% (r\Psi(\epsilon_{1},\epsilon_{2},r)+\sqrt{K}(\kappa(W_{L})^{2}-1)\right)^{2}}{% 2N\kappa(W_{L})(1+\epsilon_{1})}.‚â• divide start_ARG ( square-root start_ARG italic_N end_ARG - italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_N ( italic_Œ∫ ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - ( italic_r roman_Œ® ( italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_r ) + square-root start_ARG italic_K end_ARG ( italic_Œ∫ ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_N italic_Œ∫ ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ( 1 + italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG . (5)

The restrictions œµ1‚â§sK‚Å¢(Y)subscriptitalic-œµ1subscriptùë†ùêæùëå\epsilon_{1}\leq s_{K}(Y)italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â§ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Y ) and œµ1‚â§(K‚àí1)‚Å¢N4‚Å¢Ksubscriptitalic-œµ1ùêæ1ùëÅ4ùêæ\epsilon_{1}\leq\sqrt{\frac{(K-1)N}{4K}}italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â§ square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG ( italic_K - 1 ) italic_N end_ARG start_ARG 4 italic_K end_ARG end_ARG are mild, and we are interested in the regime in which œµ1subscriptitalic-œµ1\epsilon_{1}italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is small. In words, (2) shows that, when œµ1,œµ2‚âà0subscriptitalic-œµ1subscriptitalic-œµ20\epsilon_{1},\epsilon_{2}\approx 0italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚âà 0 (i.e., the network approximately interpolates the data in a balanced way), Œ®‚Å¢(œµ1,œµ2,r)‚âà0Œ®subscriptitalic-œµ1subscriptitalic-œµ2ùëü0\Psi(\epsilon_{1},\epsilon_{2},r)\approx 0roman_Œ® ( italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_r ) ‚âà 0 and the within-class variability (which captures NC1) vanishes. If in addition the depth of the linear part of the network grows, the RHS of (3) approaches 1, i.e., the last weight matrix WLsubscriptùëäùêøW_{L}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is close to orthogonal. This implies that (i) ZL‚àí1subscriptùëçùêø1Z_{L-1}italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is also close to orthogonal (which captures NC2), and (ii) the weights in the last layer align with ZL‚àí1subscriptùëçùêø1Z_{L-1}italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (which captures NC3). In fact, when Œ®‚Å¢(œµ1,œµ2,r)‚âà0Œ®subscriptitalic-œµ1subscriptitalic-œµ2ùëü0\Psi(\epsilon_{1},\epsilon_{2},r)\approx 0roman_Œ® ( italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_r ) ‚âà 0 and Œ∫‚Å¢(WL)‚âà1ùúÖsubscriptùëäùêø1\kappa(W_{L})\approx 1italic_Œ∫ ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ‚âà 1, the RHS of both (4) and (5) is close to 1111. Below we give a proof sketch deferring the complete argument to Appendix B.

Proof sketch.

We start with NC1. If ZLsubscriptùëçùêøZ_{L}italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is already well-collapsed (which is guaranteed by the approximate interpolation) and WLsubscriptùëäùêøW_{L}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is well-conditioned, then the only source of within-class variability in ZL‚àí1subscriptùëçùêø1Z_{L-1}italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is within the null space of WL.subscriptùëäùêøW_{L}.italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . However, if WLsubscriptùëäùêøW_{L}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and WL‚àí1subscriptùëäùêø1W_{L-1}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are balanced, the image of ZL‚àí1subscriptùëçùêø1Z_{L-1}italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT must be approximately in a subspace of the row space of WLsubscriptùëäùêøW_{L}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and, hence, ZL‚àí1subscriptùëçùêø1Z_{L-1}italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT has little freedom within the kernel of WLsubscriptùëäùêøW_{L}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. More formally, consider first the case of perfect balancedness (i.e., œµ2=0subscriptitalic-œµ20\epsilon_{2}=0italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0), and denote by WL+superscriptsubscriptùëäùêøW_{L}^{+}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT the pseudo-inverse of WLsubscriptùëäùêøW_{L}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Then, Im‚Å¢(ZL‚àí1)‚äÇIm‚Å¢(WL‚ä§)Imsubscriptùëçùêø1Imsuperscriptsubscriptùëäùêøtop\text{Im}(Z_{L-1})\subset\text{Im}(W_{L}^{\top})Im ( italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ‚äÇ Im ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) and

‚à•WL+‚Å¢WL‚Å¢ZL‚àí1‚àíWL+‚Å¢Y‚à•F=‚à•ZL‚àí1‚àíWL+‚Å¢Y‚à•F‚â§œµ1sK‚Å¢(WL).subscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptsubscriptùëäùêøsubscriptùëäùêøsubscriptùëçùêø1superscriptsubscriptùëäùêøùëåùêπsubscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùëçùêø1superscriptsubscriptùëäùêøùëåùêπsubscriptitalic-œµ1subscriptùë†ùêæsubscriptùëäùêø\left\lVert W_{L}^{+}W_{L}Z_{L-1}-W_{L}^{+}Y\right\rVert_{F}=\left\lVert Z_{L-% 1}-W_{L}^{+}Y\right\rVert_{F}\leq\frac{\epsilon_{1}}{s_{K}(W_{L})}.‚à• italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ‚à• italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â§ divide start_ARG italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG . (6)

As sK‚Å¢(WL)subscriptùë†ùêæsubscriptùëäùêøs_{K}(W_{L})italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) can be lower bounded by using the assumptions on approximate interpolation and boundedness of representations, the RHS of (6) is small and, therefore, ZL‚àí1subscriptùëçùêø1Z_{L-1}italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is close to a matrix with zero within-class variability. Moving to the case œµ2‚â†0subscriptitalic-œµ20\epsilon_{2}\neq 0italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â† 0, we need to show that WL+‚Å¢WL‚Å¢ZL‚àí1superscriptsubscriptùëäùêøsubscriptùëäùêøsubscriptùëçùêø1W_{L}^{+}W_{L}Z_{L-1}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is close to ZL‚àí1.subscriptùëçùêø1Z_{L-1}.italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . As WL+‚Å¢WLsuperscriptsubscriptùëäùêøsubscriptùëäùêøW_{L}^{+}W_{L}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT projects onto the row-space of WL,subscriptùëäùêøW_{L},italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , only the part of ZL‚àí1subscriptùëçùêø1Z_{L-1}italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in the kernel of WLsubscriptùëäùêøW_{L}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT has to be considered. This part is controlled after writing ZL‚àí1=WL‚àí1‚Å¢ZL‚àí2subscriptùëçùêø1subscriptùëäùêø1subscriptùëçùêø2Z_{L-1}=W_{L-1}Z_{L-2}italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, using the boundedness of ZL‚àí2subscriptùëçùêø2Z_{L-2}italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the approximate balancedness between WLsubscriptùëäùêøW_{L}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and WL‚àí1.subscriptùëäùêø1W_{L-1}.italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . Finally, as ZL‚àí1subscriptùëçùêø1Z_{L-1}italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is close to WL+‚Å¢Y,superscriptsubscriptùëäùêøùëåW_{L}^{+}Y,italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y , a direct computation yields the bound on NC1.

Next, to bound Œ∫‚Å¢(WL),ùúÖsubscriptùëäùêø\kappa(W_{L}),italic_Œ∫ ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , we notice that (WL‚Å¢WL‚ä§)L2‚àí(WL:L1+1‚Å¢WL:L1+1‚ä§)superscriptsubscriptùëäùêøsuperscriptsubscriptùëäùêøtopsubscriptùêø2subscriptùëä:ùêøsubscriptùêø11superscriptsubscriptùëä:ùêøsubscriptùêø11top(W_{L}W_{L}^{\top})^{L_{2}}-(W_{L:L_{1}+1}W_{L:L_{1}+1}^{\top})( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L : italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L : italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) has small operator norm, since the weights of linear layers are approximately balanced. This allows to upper bound Œ∫‚Å¢(WL)2‚Å¢L2ùúÖsuperscriptsubscriptùëäùêø2subscriptùêø2\kappa(W_{L})^{2L_{2}}italic_Œ∫ ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in terms of Œ∫‚Å¢(WL:L1+1)ùúÖsubscriptùëä:ùêøsubscriptùêø11\kappa(W_{L:L_{1}+1})italic_Œ∫ ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L : italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) (plus a small perturbation), which gives (3).

To lower bound the NC3 metric, we rescale ZL‚àí1subscriptùëçùêø1Z_{L-1}italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and WLsubscriptùëäùêøW_{L}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to ZL‚àí1‚Ä≤subscriptsuperscriptùëç‚Ä≤ùêø1Z^{\prime}_{L-1}italic_Z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and WL‚Ä≤subscriptsuperscriptùëä‚Ä≤ùêøW^{\prime}_{L}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, so that their columns and rows, respectively, have roughly equal size. Then, we reformulate the problem to proving that ‚ü®ZL‚àí1‚Ä≤,WL‚Ä≤‚Å¢Y‚ü©subscriptsuperscriptùëç‚Ä≤ùêø1subscriptsuperscriptùëä‚Ä≤ùêøùëå\left\langle Z^{\prime}_{L-1},W^{\prime}_{L}Y\right\rangle‚ü® italic_Z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Y ‚ü© is close to its theoretical maximum. We proceed to show this by arguing that, in this scaling and given that WLsubscriptùëäùêøW_{L}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is sufficiently well-conditioned, WL‚Ä≤subscriptsuperscriptùëä‚Ä≤ùêøW^{\prime}_{L}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be replaced by (WL‚Ä≤)+superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptùëä‚Ä≤ùêø(W^{\prime}_{L})^{+}( italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. As ZL‚àí1subscriptùëçùêø1Z_{L-1}italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is close to WL+‚Å¢YsuperscriptsubscriptùëäùêøùëåW_{L}^{+}Yitalic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y, we obtain (5). Finally, the bound on NC2 in (4) follows by combining (3) with the closeness between ZL‚àí1subscriptùëçùêø1Z_{L-1}italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and WL+‚Å¢YsuperscriptsubscriptùëäùêøùëåW_{L}^{+}Yitalic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y already obtained in the proof of NC1.

4 Gradient Descent Leads to No Within-Class Variability (NC1)

In this section, we show that NC1 holds for a class of neural networks with one wide layer followed by a pyramidal topology, as considered in Nguyen & Mondelli (2020). To do so, we show that the balancedness and interpolation conditions of Theorem 3.1 holds. We expect that similar conditions ‚Äì and, therefore, NC1 ‚Äì also hold under minimal over-parameterization and for ReLU networks, adapting e.g. the approach of Bombari et al. (2022) and Zou & Gu (2019), respectively.

We consider a neural network as in (1), and we minimize the ŒªùúÜ\lambdaitalic_Œª-regularized square loss CŒª‚Å¢(Œ∏)=12‚Å¢‚à•zL‚Å¢(Œ∏)‚àíy‚à•22+Œª2‚Å¢‚à•Œ∏‚à•22subscriptùê∂ùúÜùúÉ12superscriptsubscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùëßùêøùúÉùë¶22ùúÜ2superscriptsubscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•ùúÉ22C_{\lambda}(\theta)=\frac{1}{2}\left\lVert z_{L}(\theta)-y\right\rVert_{2}^{2}% +\frac{\lambda}{2}\left\lVert\theta\right\rVert_{2}^{2}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œª end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Œ∏ ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ‚à• italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Œ∏ ) - italic_y ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + divide start_ARG italic_Œª end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ‚à• italic_Œ∏ ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where zLsubscriptùëßùêøz_{L}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and yùë¶yitalic_y are obtained by vectorizing ZLsubscriptùëçùêøZ_{L}italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and YùëåYitalic_Y, respectively, and Œ∏ùúÉ\thetaitalic_Œ∏ collects all the parameters of the network. To do so, we consider the gradient descent (GD) update Œ∏k+1=Œ∏k‚àíŒ∑‚Å¢‚àáCŒª‚Å¢(Œ∏k)subscriptùúÉùëò1subscriptùúÉùëòùúÇ‚àásubscriptùê∂ùúÜsubscriptùúÉùëò\theta_{k+1}=\theta_{k}-\eta\nabla C_{\lambda}(\theta_{k})italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Œ∑ ‚àá italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œª end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), where Œ∑ùúÇ\etaitalic_Œ∑ is the step size and Œ∏k=(W‚Ñìk)‚Ñì=1LsubscriptùúÉùëòsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptùëä‚Ñìùëò‚Ñì1ùêø\theta_{k}=(W_{\ell}^{k})_{\ell=1}^{L}italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT contains all parameters at step k.ùëòk.italic_k . We also denote by Z‚Ñìksuperscriptsubscriptùëç‚ÑìùëòZ_{\ell}^{k}italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT the output of layer ‚Ñì‚Ñì\ellroman_‚Ñì after kùëòkitalic_k steps of GD. We make the following assumption on the pyramidal topology of the network, noting that this requirement is also common in prior work on the loss landscape (Nguyen & Hein, 2017, 2018).

Assumption 4.1.

(Pyramidal network topology) Let n1‚â•Nsubscriptùëõ1ùëÅn_{1}\geq Nitalic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â• italic_N and n2‚â•n3‚â•‚Ä¶‚â•nL.subscriptùëõ2subscriptùëõ3‚Ä¶subscriptùëõùêøn_{2}\geq n_{3}\geq\ldots\geq n_{L}.italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â• italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â• ‚Ä¶ ‚â• italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

We make the following assumptions on the activation function œÉùúé\sigmaitalic_œÉ of the non-linear layers.

Assumption 4.2.

(Activation function) Fix Œ≥‚àà(0,1)ùõæ01\gamma\in(0,1)italic_Œ≥ ‚àà ( 0 , 1 ) and Œ≤‚â•1ùõΩ1\beta\geq 1italic_Œ≤ ‚â• 1. Let œÉùúé\sigmaitalic_œÉ satisfy that: (i) œÉ‚Ä≤‚Å¢(x)‚àà[Œ≥,1]superscriptùúé‚Ä≤ùë•ùõæ1\sigma^{\prime}(x)\in[\gamma,1]italic_œÉ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x ) ‚àà [ italic_Œ≥ , 1 ], (ii) |œÉ‚Å¢(x)|‚â§|x|ùúéùë•ùë•|\sigma(x)|\leq|x|| italic_œÉ ( italic_x ) | ‚â§ | italic_x | for every x‚àà‚Ñùùë•‚Ñùx\in\mathbb{R}italic_x ‚àà blackboard_R, and (iii) œÉ‚Ä≤superscriptùúé‚Ä≤\sigma^{\prime}italic_œÉ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is Œ≤ùõΩ\betaitalic_Œ≤-Lipschitz.

In principle, œÉùúé\sigmaitalic_œÉ can change at all layers, as long as it satisfies the above assumption. As an example, one can consider a family of parameterized ReLU functions, smoothened by a Gaussian kernel:

œÉ‚Å¢(x)=‚àí(1‚àíŒ≥)22‚Å¢œÄ‚Å¢Œ≤+Œ≤1‚àíŒ≥‚Å¢‚à´‚àí‚àû‚àûmax(Œ≥‚Å¢u,u)‚Å¢e‚àíœÄ‚Å¢Œ≤2‚Å¢(x‚àíu)2(1‚àíŒ≥)2‚Å¢d‚Å¢u.ùúéùë•superscript1ùõæ22ùúãùõΩùõΩ1ùõæsuperscriptsubscriptmaxùõæùë¢ùë¢superscriptùëíùúãsuperscriptùõΩ2superscriptùë•ùë¢2superscript1ùõæ2ùëëùë¢\displaystyle\sigma(x)=-\frac{(1-\gamma)^{2}}{2\pi\beta}+\frac{\beta}{1-\gamma% }\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\mathop{\rm max}\nolimits(\gamma u,u)\,e^{-\frac{\pi% \beta^{2}(x-u)^{2}}{(1-\gamma)^{2}}}du.italic_œÉ ( italic_x ) = - divide start_ARG ( 1 - italic_Œ≥ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_œÄ italic_Œ≤ end_ARG + divide start_ARG italic_Œ≤ end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_Œ≥ end_ARG ‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT - ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_max ( italic_Œ≥ italic_u , italic_u ) italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - divide start_ARG italic_œÄ italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x - italic_u ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 - italic_Œ≥ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d italic_u . (7)

One can readily verify that the activation in (7) satisfies Assumption 4.2 and it uniformly approximates the ReLU function over ‚Ñù‚Ñù\mathbb{R}blackboard_R, see Lemma B.1 in Nguyen & Mondelli (2020). Next, let us introduce some notation111To avoid confusion, we note that this notation is different from the one used in (Nguyen & Mondelli, 2020). for the singular values of the weight matrices at initialization Œ∏0=(W‚Ñì0)‚Ñì=1LsubscriptùúÉ0superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptùëä‚Ñì0‚Ñì1ùêø\theta_{0}=(W_{\ell}^{0})_{\ell=1}^{L}italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT:

Œª‚Ñì=œÉmin‚Å¢(W‚Ñì0),Œª¬Ø‚Ñì=‚à•W‚Ñì0‚à•o‚Å¢p+min‚Ñì‚àà{3,‚Ä¶,L}Œª‚Ñì,Œªi‚Üíj=‚àè‚Ñì=ijŒª‚Ñì,Œª¬Øi‚Üíj=‚àè‚Ñì=ijŒª¬Ø‚Ñì.formulae-sequencesubscriptùúÜ‚Ñìsubscriptùúéminsuperscriptsubscriptùëä‚Ñì0formulae-sequencesubscript¬ØùúÜ‚Ñìsubscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptsubscriptùëä‚Ñì0ùëúùëùsubscriptmin‚Ñì3‚Ä¶ùêøsubscriptùúÜ‚Ñìformulae-sequencesubscriptùúÜ‚Üíùëñùëósuperscriptsubscriptproduct‚ÑìùëñùëósubscriptùúÜ‚Ñìsubscript¬ØùúÜ‚Üíùëñùëósuperscriptsubscriptproduct‚Ñìùëñùëósubscript¬ØùúÜ‚Ñì\begin{split}&\lambda_{\ell}=\sigma_{\textrm{min}}\left(W_{\ell}^{0}\right),\,% \,\,\,\bar{\lambda}_{\ell}=\left\lVert W_{\ell}^{0}\right\rVert_{op}+\mathop{% \rm min}\nolimits_{\ell\in\{3,\ldots,L\}}\lambda_{\ell},\,\,\,\,\lambda_{i\to j% }=\prod_{\ell=i}^{j}\lambda_{\ell},\,\,\,\,\bar{\lambda}_{i\to j}=\prod_{\ell=% i}^{j}\bar{\lambda}_{\ell}.\\ \end{split}start_ROW start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL italic_Œª start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT min end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , over¬Ø start_ARG italic_Œª end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ‚à• italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì ‚àà { 3 , ‚Ä¶ , italic_L } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œª start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Œª start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ‚Üí italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ‚àè start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì = italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œª start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , over¬Ø start_ARG italic_Œª end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ‚Üí italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ‚àè start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì = italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over¬Ø start_ARG italic_Œª end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . end_CELL end_ROW (8)

We also define ŒªF=œÉmin‚Å¢(œÉ‚Å¢(W10‚Å¢X))subscriptùúÜùêπsubscriptùúéminùúésuperscriptsubscriptùëä10ùëã\lambda_{F}=\sigma_{\textrm{min}}\left(\sigma(W_{1}^{0}X)\right)italic_Œª start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT min end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_œÉ ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_X ) ) as the smallest singular value of the output of the first hidden layer at initialization. Finally, we make the following assumption on the initialization.

Assumption 4.3.

(Initial conditions)

ŒªF‚Å¢Œª3‚ÜíL‚Å¢min(ŒªF,min‚Ñì‚àà{3,‚Ä¶,L}Œª‚Ñì)‚â•8‚Å¢Œ≥‚Å¢(2Œ≥)L‚Å¢C0‚Å¢(Œ∏0).subscriptùúÜùêπsubscriptùúÜ‚Üí3ùêøminsubscriptùúÜùêπsubscriptmin‚Ñì3‚Ä¶ùêøsubscriptùúÜ‚Ñì8ùõæsuperscript2ùõæùêøsubscriptùê∂0subscriptùúÉ0\displaystyle\lambda_{F}\lambda_{3\to L}\mathop{\rm min}\nolimits(\lambda_{F},% \mathop{\rm min}\nolimits_{\ell\in\{3,\ldots,L\}}\lambda_{\ell})\geq 8\gamma% \sqrt{\left(\frac{2}{\gamma}\right)^{L}C_{0}(\theta_{0})}.italic_Œª start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œª start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 ‚Üí italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_min ( italic_Œª start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì ‚àà { 3 , ‚Ä¶ , italic_L } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œª start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ‚â• 8 italic_Œ≥ square-root start_ARG ( divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Œ≥ end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG . (9)

We note that (9) can be satisfied by choosing a sufficiently small initialization for the second layer and a sufficiently large one for the remaining layers. In fact, the LHS of (9) depends on all the layer weights except the second, so this quantity can be made arbitrarily large. Next, by taking a sufficiently small second layer, the term 2‚Å¢C0‚Å¢(Œ∏)=‚ÄñZL‚àíY‚ÄñF2subscriptùê∂0ùúÉsubscriptnormsubscriptùëçùêøùëåùêπ\sqrt{2C_{0}(\theta)}=\|Z_{L}-Y\|_{F}square-root start_ARG 2 italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Œ∏ ) end_ARG = ‚à• italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Y ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be upper bounded by 2‚Å¢‚ÄñY‚ÄñF2subscriptnormùëåùêπ2\|Y\|_{F}2 ‚à• italic_Y ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. As a consequence, the RHS of (9) is at most 8‚Å¢2‚Å¢‚ÄñY‚ÄñF‚Å¢Œ≥‚Å¢(2Œ≥)L/282subscriptnormùëåùêπùõæsuperscript2ùõæùêø28\sqrt{2}\|Y\|_{F}\gamma\big{(}\frac{2}{\gamma}\big{)}^{L/2}8 square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG ‚à• italic_Y ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ≥ ( divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Œ≥ end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. As the LHS of (9) can be arbitrarily large, the inequality holds for a suitable initialization.

Theorem 4.4.

Let the network satisfy Assumption 4.1, œÉùúé\sigmaitalic_œÉ satisfy Assumption 4.2 and the initial conditions satisfy Assumption 4.3. start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 ‚Üí italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Then, we have that

NC1‚Å¢(ZL‚àí1k)‚â§r2N‚Å¢Œ®‚Å¢(œµ1‚Å¢2,œµ2,r)(K‚àí1K‚àí2‚Å¢2N‚Å¢œµ1)2,NC1superscriptsubscriptùëçùêø1ùëòsuperscriptùëü2ùëÅŒ®subscriptitalic-œµ12subscriptitalic-œµ2ùëüsuperscriptùêæ1ùêæ22ùëÅsubscriptitalic-œµ12\text{NC1}(Z_{L-1}^{k})\leq\frac{r^{2}}{N}\frac{\Psi(\epsilon_{1}\sqrt{2},% \epsilon_{2},r)}{\left(\sqrt{\frac{K-1}{K}}-\frac{2\sqrt{2}}{\sqrt{N}}\epsilon% _{1}\right)^{2}},NC1 ( italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ‚â§ divide start_ARG italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_N end_ARG divide start_ARG roman_Œ® ( italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG , italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_r ) end_ARG start_ARG ( square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_K - 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG end_ARG - divide start_ARG 2 square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_N end_ARG end_ARG italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG , (11)

with Œ®‚Å¢(œµ1,œµ2,r)=r‚Å¢(œµ1sK‚Å¢(Y)‚àíœµ1+nL‚àí1‚Å¢œµ2)Œ®subscriptitalic-œµ1subscriptitalic-œµ2ùëüùëüsubscriptitalic-œµ1subscriptùë†ùêæùëåsubscriptitalic-œµ1subscriptùëõùêø1subscriptitalic-œµ2\Psi(\epsilon_{1},\epsilon_{2},r)=r\left(\frac{\epsilon_{1}}{s_{K}(Y)-\epsilon% _{1}}+\sqrt{n_{L-1}\epsilon_{2}}\right)roman_Œ® ( italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_r ) = italic_r ( divide start_ARG italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Y ) - italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG + square-root start_ARG italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) and

r=max(œµ1‚Å¢2Œª,(œµ1‚Å¢2Œª)L‚àí2‚Å¢‚ÄñX‚Äño‚Å¢p,(œµ1‚Å¢2Œª)L‚àí1‚Å¢‚ÄñX‚Äño‚Å¢p).ùëümaxsubscriptitalic-œµ12ùúÜsuperscriptsubscriptitalic-œµ12ùúÜùêø2subscriptnormùëãùëúùëùsuperscriptsubscriptitalic-œµ12ùúÜùêø1subscriptnormùëãùëúùëùr=\mathop{\rm max}\nolimits\left(\epsilon_{1}\sqrt{\frac{2}{\lambda}},\left(% \epsilon_{1}\sqrt{\frac{2}{\lambda}}\right)^{L-2}\|X\|_{op},\left(\epsilon_{1}% \sqrt{\frac{2}{\lambda}}\right)^{L-1}\|X\|_{op}\right).italic_r = roman_max ( italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Œª end_ARG end_ARG , ( italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Œª end_ARG end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L - 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• italic_X ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ( italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Œª end_ARG end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• italic_X ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) . (12)

In words, if regularization and learning rate are small enough and we run GD for sufficiently long (as in (10)), then the within-class variability vanishes (as in (11)). To interpret the result, note that the NC1 metric tends to 00 (i.e., the collapse is perfect) as œµ1,œµ2‚Üí0‚Üísubscriptitalic-œµ1subscriptitalic-œµ20\epsilon_{1},\epsilon_{2}\to 0italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚Üí 0. Since the terms Œ≤1,mŒª,r0,Œ±subscriptùõΩ1subscriptùëöùúÜsubscriptùëü0ùõº\beta_{1},m_{\lambda},r_{0},\alphaitalic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œª end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Œ± do not depend on œµ1,œµ2subscriptitalic-œµ1subscriptitalic-œµ2\epsilon_{1},\epsilon_{2}italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (but just on the network architecture and initialization), taking ŒªùúÜ\lambdaitalic_Œª of order œµ12superscriptsubscriptitalic-œµ12\epsilon_{1}^{2}italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and Œ∑ùúÇ\etaitalic_Œ∑ of order œµ2subscriptitalic-œµ2\epsilon_{2}italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT satisfies the first two requirements in (10), also giving that rùëüritalic_r in (12) is of constant order. Finally, as log‚Å°(1‚àíx)‚âà‚àíx1ùë•ùë•\log(1-x)\approx-xroman_log ( 1 - italic_x ) ‚âà - italic_x for small xùë•xitalic_x, the quantity Œ∑‚Å¢kùúÇùëò\eta kitalic_Œ∑ italic_k ‚Äì which quantifies the time of the dynamics, since it is the product of learning rate and number of GD steps ‚Äì is of order log‚Å°(1/Œª)+log‚Å°(1/œµ2)/Œª1ùúÜ1subscriptitalic-œµ2ùúÜ\log(1/\lambda)+\log(1/\epsilon_{2})/\lambdaroman_log ( 1 / italic_Œª ) + roman_log ( 1 / italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / italic_Œª. Below we provide a proof sketch deferring the full argument to Appendix B.

Proof sketch.

We show that the network trained via ŒªùúÜ\lambdaitalic_Œª-regularized GD fulfills the three sufficient conditions for NC1 given by Theorem 3.1, i.e., approximate interpolation, approximate balancedness and bounded representations/weights. To do so, we distinguish two phases in the training dynamics.

The first phase lasts for logarithmic time in 1/Œª1ùúÜ1/\lambda1 / italic_Œª (or, equivalently, 1/œµ11subscriptitalic-œµ11/\epsilon_{1}1 / italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) and, here, the loss decreases exponentially fast to a value of at most 2‚Å¢Œª‚Å¢mŒª‚â§œµ122ùúÜsubscriptùëöùúÜsuperscriptsubscriptitalic-œµ122\lambda m_{\lambda}\leq\epsilon_{1}^{2}2 italic_Œª italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œª end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â§ italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. As the learning rate is small enough, the loss cannot increase during the GD dynamics, which already gives approximate interpolation. To show the exponential convergence, we proceed in two steps. First, Lemma 4.1 in (Nguyen & Mondelli, 2020) gives that the unregularized loss C0‚Å¢(Œ∏)subscriptùê∂0ùúÉC_{0}(\theta)italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Œ∏ ) satisfies the Polyak-Lojasiewicz (PL) inequality

‚Äñ‚àáC0‚Å¢(Œ∏)‚Äñ22‚â•Œ±2‚Å¢C0‚Å¢(Œ∏),superscriptsubscriptnorm‚àásubscriptùê∂0ùúÉ22ùõº2subscriptùê∂0ùúÉ\left\|\nabla C_{0}(\theta)\right\|_{2}^{2}\geq\frac{\alpha}{2}C_{0}(\theta),‚à• ‚àá italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Œ∏ ) ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚â• divide start_ARG italic_Œ± end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Œ∏ ) , (13)

for all Œ∏ùúÉ\thetaitalic_Œ∏ in a ball centered at initialization Œ∏0subscriptùúÉ0\theta_{0}italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and with sufficiently large radius (captured by r0subscriptùëü0r_{0}italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT). Next, we show that, if C0‚Å¢(Œ∏)subscriptùê∂0ùúÉC_{0}(\theta)italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Œ∏ ) satisfies the Œ±ùõº\alphaitalic_Œ±-PL inequality in (13), then the regularized loss CŒª‚Å¢(Œ∏)=C0‚Å¢(Œ∏)+Œª2‚Å¢‚ÄñŒ∏‚Äñ22subscriptùê∂ùúÜùúÉsubscriptùê∂0ùúÉùúÜ2superscriptsubscriptnormùúÉ22C_{\lambda}(\theta)=C_{0}(\theta)+\frac{\lambda}{2}\left\|\theta\right\|_{2}^{2}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œª end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Œ∏ ) = italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Œ∏ ) + divide start_ARG italic_Œª end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ‚à• italic_Œ∏ ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT satisfies a shifted Œ±ùõº\alphaitalic_Œ±-PL inequality, which implies exponential convergence. This second step is formalized by the proposition below proved in Appendix B.

Proposition 4.5.

Let C0‚Å¢(Œ∏)subscriptùê∂0ùúÉC_{0}(\theta)italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Œ∏ ) satisfy the Œ±ùõº\alphaitalic_Œ±-PL inequality (13) in the ball B‚Å¢(Œ∏0,r0)ùêµsubscriptùúÉ0subscriptùëü0B(\theta_{0},r_{0})italic_B ( italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Then, in the same ball, CŒª‚Å¢(Œ∏)subscriptùê∂ùúÜùúÉC_{\lambda}(\theta)italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œª end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Œ∏ ) satisfies the inequality

‚à•‚àáCŒª(Œ∏))‚à•22‚â•Œ±4(CŒª(Œ∏)‚àíŒªmŒª),\left\|\nabla C_{\lambda}(\theta))\right\|_{2}^{2}\geq\frac{\alpha}{4}\left(C_% {\lambda}(\theta)-\lambda m_{\lambda}\right),‚à• ‚àá italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œª end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Œ∏ ) ) ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚â• divide start_ARG italic_Œ± end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG ( italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œª end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Œ∏ ) - italic_Œª italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œª end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , (14)

where mŒª=(1+4‚Å¢Œª/Œ±)2‚Å¢(‚ÄñŒ∏0‚Äñ2+r0)2subscriptùëöùúÜsuperscript14ùúÜùõº2superscriptsubscriptnormsubscriptùúÉ02subscriptùëü02m_{\lambda}=(1+\sqrt{4\lambda/\alpha})^{2}\left(\left\|\theta_{0}\right\|_{2}+% r_{0}\right)^{2}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œª end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( 1 + square-root start_ARG 4 italic_Œª / italic_Œ± end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( ‚à• italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.
