(16)

The second phase lasts for linear time in 1/Œª1ùúÜ1/\lambda1 / italic_Œª (or, equivalently in 1/œµ121superscriptsubscriptitalic-œµ121/\epsilon_{1}^{2}1 / italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT) and logarithmic time in 1/œµ21subscriptitalic-œµ21/\epsilon_{2}1 / italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and, here, the weight matrices in the linear part of the network become balanced. More precisely, we show that, if W‚Ñìsubscriptùëä‚ÑìW_{\ell}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a weight matrix of the linear part, ‚ÄñW‚Ñì+1‚ä§‚Å¢W‚Ñì+1‚àíW‚Ñì‚Å¢W‚Ñì‚ä§‚Äño‚Å¢psubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptùëä‚Ñì1topsubscriptùëä‚Ñì1subscriptùëä‚Ñìsuperscriptsubscriptùëä‚Ñìtopùëúùëù\|W_{\ell+1}^{\top}W_{\ell+1}-W_{\ell}W_{\ell}^{\top}\|_{op}‚à• italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT decreases exponentially and the exponent scales with 1/Œª1ùúÜ1/\lambda1 / italic_Œª, which gives approximate balancedness. Finally, as the regularization term in the loss is at most œµ12superscriptsubscriptitalic-œµ12\epsilon_{1}^{2}italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the operator norm of representations and weight matrices is bounded by rùëüritalic_r as in (12), and the proof is completed by an application of Theorem 3.1.

5 Orthogonality of Class Means (NC2) and Alignment with Last Weight Matrix (NC3)

To guarantee the orthogonality of class means and their alignment with the last weight matrix, the crux is to show that the condition number Œ∫‚Å¢(WL)ùúÖsubscriptùëäùêø\kappa(W_{L})italic_Œ∫ ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) of the last weight matrix WLsubscriptùëäùêøW_{L}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is close to one. In fact, as ZL‚àí1‚âàWL+‚Å¢Ysubscriptùëçùêø1superscriptsubscriptùëäùêøùëåZ_{L-1}\approx W_{L}^{+}Yitalic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚âà italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y, this implies that the last hidden representation ZL‚àí1subscriptùëçùêø1Z_{L-1}italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is approximately a rotation and rescaling of YùëåYitalic_Y, which gives NC2, and a bound on NC3 of the form in (5) also follows.

The fact that Œ∫‚Å¢(WL)‚âà1ùúÖsubscriptùëäùêø1\kappa(W_{L})\approx 1italic_Œ∫ ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ‚âà 1 is a consequence of the presence of many balanced linear layers. Indeed, balancedness implies WL‚Å¢WL‚ä§=(WL:L1+1‚Å¢WL:L1+1‚ä§)1L2subscriptùëäùêøsuperscriptsubscriptùëäùêøtopsuperscriptsubscriptùëä:ùêøsubscriptùêø11superscriptsubscriptùëä:ùêøsubscriptùêø11top1subscriptùêø2W_{L}W_{L}^{\top}=(W_{L:L_{1}+1}W_{L:L_{1}+1}^{\top})^{\frac{1}{L_{2}}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L : italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L : italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, which gives that Œ∫‚Å¢(WL)=Œ∫‚Å¢(WL:L1+1)1L2ùúÖsubscriptùëäùêøùúÖsuperscriptsubscriptùëä:ùêøsubscriptùêø111subscriptùêø2\kappa(W_{L})=\kappa(W_{L:L_{1}+1})^{\frac{1}{L_{2}}}italic_Œ∫ ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_Œ∫ ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L : italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Thus, if the conditioning of the product of the linear layers WL:L1+1subscriptùëä:ùêøsubscriptùêø11W_{L:L_{1}+1}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L : italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be bounded independently of L2subscriptùêø2L_{2}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, one can guarantee that the conditioning of WLsubscriptùëäùêøW_{L}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT approaches 1111 as L2‚Üí‚àû‚Üísubscriptùêø2L_{2}\to\inftyitalic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚Üí ‚àû. As this is difficult to obtain in full generality (in particular the assumptions of Theorem 3.1 may not be sufficient), we show that the conditioning can be controlled (i) at any global minimizer, and (ii) when the parameters are ‚Äòstable‚Äô under large learning rates.

5.1 Global Minimizers

We first show that any set of parameters that approximately interpolate with small norm has bounded condition number. We will then show that with the right choice of widths and ridge, all global minimizers satisfy these two assumptions.

Proposition 5.1.

Let œÉùúé\sigmaitalic_œÉ satisfy Assumption 4.2. Then, for any network that satisfies

  • ‚Ä¢

    approximate interpolation, i.e., ‚ÄñZL‚àíY‚ÄñF‚â§œµ1subscriptnormsubscriptùëçùêøùëåùêπsubscriptitalic-œµ1\left\|Z_{L}-Y\right\|_{F}\leq\epsilon_{1}‚à• italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Y ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â§ italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT,

  • ‚Ä¢

    bounded parameters, i.e., ‚ÄñŒ∏‚Äñ22‚â§L‚Å¢K+csuperscriptsubscriptnormùúÉ22ùêøùêæùëê\left\|\theta\right\|_{2}^{2}\leq LK+c‚à• italic_Œ∏ ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚â§ italic_L italic_K + italic_c,

the linear part WL:L1+1subscriptùëä:ùêøsubscriptùêø11W_{L:L_{1}+1}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L : italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT satisfies

Œ∫‚Å¢(WL:L1+1)‚â§exp‚Å°(12‚Å¢(c+L1‚Å¢K‚Å¢log‚Å°K‚àí2‚Å¢K‚Å¢log‚Å°sK‚Å¢(Y)‚àíœµ1‚ÄñX‚Äño‚Å¢p)).ùúÖsubscriptùëä:ùêøsubscriptùêø1112ùëêsubscriptùêø1ùêæùêæ2ùêæsubscriptùë†ùêæùëåsubscriptitalic-œµ1subscriptnormùëãùëúùëù\kappa(W_{L:L_{1}+1})\leq\exp\left(\frac{1}{2}\left(c+L_{1}K\log K-2K\log\frac% {s_{K}(Y)-\epsilon_{1}}{\left\|X\right\|_{op}}\right)\right).italic_Œ∫ ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L : italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ‚â§ roman_exp ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( italic_c + italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K roman_log italic_K - 2 italic_K roman_log divide start_ARG italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Y ) - italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ‚à• italic_X ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) ) . (17)
Theorem 5.2.

Let œÉùúé\sigmaitalic_œÉ satisfy Assumption 4.2. Assume there exist parameters of the nonlinear part Œ∏n‚Å¢o‚Å¢n‚Å¢l‚Å¢i‚Å¢n=(W‚Ñì)‚Ñì=1L1subscriptùúÉùëõùëúùëõùëôùëñùëõsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptùëä‚Ñì‚Ñì1subscriptùêø1\theta_{nonlin}=(W_{\ell})_{\ell=1}^{L_{1}}italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_o italic_n italic_l italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that ZL1=Ysubscriptùëçsubscriptùêø1ùëåZ_{L_{1}}=Yitalic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Y and ‚ÄñŒ∏n‚Å¢o‚Å¢n‚Å¢l‚Å¢i‚Å¢n‚Äñ22=csuperscriptsubscriptnormsubscriptùúÉùëõùëúùëõùëôùëñùëõ22ùëê\|\theta_{nonlin}\|_{2}^{2}=c‚à• italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_o italic_n italic_l italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_c. Then, at any global minimizer of the regularized loss ‚ÑíŒª‚Å¢(Œ∏)=12‚Å¢‚ÄñY‚àíZL‚ÄñF2+Œª2‚Å¢‚ÄñŒ∏‚Äñ22subscript‚ÑíùúÜùúÉ12superscriptsubscriptnormùëåsubscriptùëçùêøùêπ2ùúÜ2superscriptsubscriptnormùúÉ22\mathcal{L}_{\lambda}(\theta)=\frac{1}{2}\left\|Y-Z_{L}\right\|_{F}^{2}+\frac{% \lambda}{2}\left\|\theta\right\|_{2}^{2}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œª end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Œ∏ ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ‚à• italic_Y - italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + divide start_ARG italic_Œª end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ‚à• italic_Œ∏ ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with Œª‚â§œµ12K‚Å¢L+cùúÜsuperscriptsubscriptitalic-œµ12ùêæùêøùëê\lambda\leq\frac{\epsilon_{1}^{2}}{KL+c}italic_Œª ‚â§ divide start_ARG italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_K italic_L + italic_c end_ARG, we have

Œ∫‚Å¢(WL:L1+1)‚â§(‚ÄñX‚Äño‚Å¢psK‚Å¢(Y)‚àíœµ1)K‚Å¢exp‚Å°(12‚Å¢(c‚àíL1‚Å¢K+L1‚Å¢K‚Å¢log‚Å°K)),Œ∫‚Å¢(WL)‚â§(‚ÄñX‚Äño‚Å¢psK‚Å¢(Y)‚àíœµ1)KL1‚Å¢exp‚Å°(12‚Å¢L1‚Å¢(c‚àíL1‚Å¢K+L1‚Å¢K‚Å¢log‚Å°K)).formulae-sequenceùúÖsubscriptùëä:ùêøsubscriptùêø11superscriptsubscriptnormùëãùëúùëùsubscriptùë†ùêæùëåsubscriptitalic-œµ1ùêæ12ùëêsubscriptùêø1ùêæsubscriptùêø1ùêæùêæùúÖsubscriptùëäùêøsuperscriptsubscriptnormùëãùëúùëùsubscriptùë†ùêæùëåsubscriptitalic-œµ1ùêæsubscriptùêø112subscriptùêø1ùëêsubscriptùêø1ùêæsubscriptùêø1ùêæùêæ\begin{split}\kappa(W_{L:L_{1}+1})&\leq\left(\frac{\left\|X\right\|_{op}}{s_{K% }(Y)-\epsilon_{1}}\right)^{K}\exp\left(\frac{1}{2}\left(c-L_{1}K+L_{1}K\log K% \right)\right),\\ \kappa(W_{L})&\leq\left(\frac{\left\|X\right\|_{op}}{s_{K}(Y)-\epsilon_{1}}% \right)^{\frac{K}{L_{1}}}\exp\left(\frac{1}{2L_{1}}\left(c-L_{1}K+L_{1}K\log K% \right)\right).\end{split}start_ROW start_CELL italic_Œ∫ ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L : italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_CELL start_CELL ‚â§ ( divide start_ARG ‚à• italic_X ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Y ) - italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_exp ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( italic_c - italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K + italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K roman_log italic_K ) ) , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_Œ∫ ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_CELL start_CELL ‚â§ ( divide start_ARG ‚à• italic_X ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Y ) - italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_K end_ARG start_ARG italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_exp ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ( italic_c - italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K + italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K roman_log italic_K ) ) . end_CELL end_ROW (18)

This implies that the bounds on NC1, NC2 and NC3 in (2), (4) and (5), respectively, hold with Œ∫‚Å¢(WL)ùúÖsubscriptùëäùêø\kappa(W_{L})italic_Œ∫ ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) upper bounded as above and œµ2=0subscriptitalic-œµ20\epsilon_{2}=0italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.

The assumption that the parameters of the nonlinear part can be chosen to fit the labels YùëåYitalic_Y is guaranteed for large enough width (i) by relying on any traditional approximation result (Hornik et al., 1989; Leshno et al., 1993; Arora et al., 2018a; He et al., 2018), or (ii) by taking the infinite time limit of any convergence results (Nguyen & Mondelli, 2020), or (iii) by taking the limit Œª‚Üò0‚ÜòùúÜ0\lambda\searrow 0italic_Œª ‚Üò 0 in Proposition 4.5. A sketch of the arguments is below, with full proofs deferred to Appendix B.

Proof sketch.

To prove Proposition 5.1, we write the norm of the linear and nonlinear parts of the network in terms of the conditioning of WL:L1+1subscriptùëä:ùêøsubscriptùêø11W_{L:L_{1}+1}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L : italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT: for the linear part, this is a direct computation; for the nonlinear part, we use Theorem 1 of Dai et al. (2021), which lower bounds the norm of the parameters in terms of the product of the singular values, and then manipulate the latter quantity to obtain again the desired conditioning. Next, to prove Theorem 5.2, we pick the parameters of the nonlinear part Œ∏n‚Å¢o‚Å¢n‚Å¢l‚Å¢i‚Å¢nsubscriptùúÉùëõùëúùëõùëôùëñùëõ\theta_{nonlin}italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_o italic_n italic_l italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT s.t. ZL1=Ysubscriptùëçsubscriptùêø1ùëåZ_{L_{1}}=Yitalic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Y and ‚ÄñŒ∏n‚Å¢o‚Å¢n‚Å¢l‚Å¢i‚Å¢n‚Äñ22=csuperscriptsubscriptnormsubscriptùúÉùëõùëúùëõùëôùëñùëõ22ùëê\|\theta_{nonlin}\|_{2}^{2}=c‚à• italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_o italic_n italic_l italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_c, and set the linear layers to the identity. This leads to a total parameter norm of K‚Å¢L2+cùêæsubscriptùêø2ùëêKL_{2}+citalic_K italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_c and a regularized cost of Œª2‚Å¢(K‚Å¢L2+c)ùúÜ2ùêæsubscriptùêø2ùëê\frac{\lambda}{2}(KL_{2}+c)divide start_ARG italic_Œª end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( italic_K italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_c ), and it forces the global minimizer to satisfy the assumptions of Proposition 5.1, which gives the claim on Œ∫‚Å¢(WL:L1+1)ùúÖsubscriptùëä:ùêøsubscriptùêø11\kappa(W_{L:L_{1}+1})italic_Œ∫ ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L : italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Then, as all local minimizers have balanced linear layers, Œ∫‚Å¢(WL)=Œ∫‚Å¢(WL:L1+1)1L1ùúÖsubscriptùëäùêøùúÖsuperscriptsubscriptùëä:ùêøsubscriptùêø111subscriptùêø1\kappa(W_{L})=\kappa(W_{L:L_{1}+1})^{\frac{1}{L_{1}}}italic_Œ∫ ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_Œ∫ ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L : italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, which gives (18). Finally, the claim on NC1, NC2 and NC3 follows from an application of Theorem 3.1.

5.2 Large Learning Rates

Previous works have observed that the learning rates used in practice are typically ‚Äòtoo large‚Äô, i.e. the loss may not always be strictly decreasing and GD diverges from gradient flow (Cohen et al., 2021). Thankfully, instead of simply diverging, for large Œ∑ùúÇ\etaitalic_Œ∑ (but not too large) the parameters naturally end up at the ‚Äòedge of stability‚Äô: the top eigenvalue of the Hessian ‚Ñã‚Å¢CŒª‚Ñãsubscriptùê∂ùúÜ\mathcal{H}C_{\lambda}caligraphic_H italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œª end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is close to 2Œ∑2ùúÇ\frac{2}{\eta}divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Œ∑ end_ARG, i.e., the threshold below which GD is stable (Cohen et al., 2021; Lewkowycz et al., 2020). One can thus interpret GD with learning rate Œ∑ùúÇ\etaitalic_Œ∑ as minimizing the cost CŒªsubscriptùê∂ùúÜC_{\lambda}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œª end_POSTSUBSCRIPT amongst parameters Œ∏ùúÉ\thetaitalic_Œ∏ such that ‚Äñ‚Ñã‚Å¢CŒª‚Äño‚Å¢p<2Œ∑subscriptnorm‚Ñãsubscriptùê∂ùúÜùëúùëù2ùúÇ\left\|\mathcal{H}C_{\lambda}\right\|_{op}<\frac{2}{\eta}‚à• caligraphic_H italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œª end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Œ∑ end_ARG. These observations are supported by strong empirical evidence and have been also proved theoretically for simple models (Damian et al., 2022), although a general result remains difficult to prove due to the chaotic behavior of GD for large Œ∑ùúÇ\etaitalic_Œ∑. Specifically, the Hessian has the form

‚Ñã‚Å¢CŒª‚Å¢(Œ∏)=(‚àáŒ∏ZL)‚ä§‚Å¢‚àÇŒ∏ZL+Tr‚Å¢[(Y‚àíZL)‚Å¢‚àáŒ∏2ZL]+Œª‚Å¢IP,‚Ñãsubscriptùê∂ùúÜùúÉsuperscriptsubscript‚àáùúÉsubscriptùëçùêøtopsubscriptùúÉsubscriptùëçùêøTrdelimited-[]ùëåsubscriptùëçùêøsuperscriptsubscript‚àáùúÉ2subscriptùëçùêøùúÜsubscriptùêºùëÉ\mathcal{H}C_{\lambda}(\theta)=\left(\nabla_{\theta}Z_{L}\right)^{\top}% \partial_{\theta}Z_{L}+\mathrm{Tr}\left[(Y-Z_{L})\nabla_{\theta}^{2}Z_{L}% \right]+\lambda I_{P},caligraphic_H italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œª end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Œ∏ ) = ( ‚àá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ∏ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àÇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ∏ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + roman_Tr [ ( italic_Y - italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ‚àá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ∏ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] + italic_Œª italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (19)

with ‚àáŒ∏ZL‚àà‚ÑùP√óN‚Å¢Ksubscript‚àáùúÉsubscriptùëçùêøsuperscript‚ÑùùëÉùëÅùêæ\nabla_{\theta}Z_{L}\in\mathbb{R}^{P\times NK}‚àá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ∏ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_P √ó italic_N italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and PùëÉPitalic_P the number of parameters. The first term is the Fisher information matrix: this is dual to the Neural Tangent Kernel (NTK) Œò=‚àáŒ∏ZL‚Å¢(‚àáŒ∏ZL)‚ä§‚àà‚ÑùN‚Å¢K√óN‚Å¢KŒòsubscript‚àáùúÉsubscriptùëçùêøsuperscriptsubscript‚àáùúÉsubscriptùëçùêøtopsuperscript‚ÑùùëÅùêæùëÅùêæ\Theta=\nabla_{\theta}Z_{L}\left(\nabla_{\theta}Z_{L}\right)^{\top}\in\mathbb{% R}^{NK\times NK}roman_Œò = ‚àá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ∏ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( ‚àá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ∏ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N italic_K √ó italic_N italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (Jacot et al., 2018). Therefore, at approximately interpolating points, we have ‚Äñ‚Ñã‚Å¢CŒª‚Å¢(Œ∏)‚Äño‚Å¢p=‚ÄñŒò‚Äño‚Å¢p+O‚Å¢(œµ1)+O‚Å¢(Œª)subscriptnorm‚Ñãsubscriptùê∂ùúÜùúÉùëúùëùsubscriptnormŒòùëúùëùùëÇsubscriptitalic-œµ1ùëÇùúÜ\left\|\mathcal{H}C_{\lambda}(\theta)\right\|_{op}=\left\|\Theta\right\|_{op}+% O(\epsilon_{1})+O(\lambda)‚à• caligraphic_H italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œª end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Œ∏ ) ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ‚à• roman_Œò ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_O ( italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + italic_O ( italic_Œª ), where œµ1subscriptitalic-œµ1\epsilon_{1}italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the interpolation error and ŒªùúÜ\lambdaitalic_Œª the regularization parameter. We can thus interpret large learning as forcing a bound on the operator norm of the NTK. For networks that approximately interpolate the data with bounded NTK and bounded weights, the following proposition guarantees good conditioning of the weights in the linear part (and therefore NC2-3).

Proposition 5.3.

For any network that satisfies

  • ‚Ä¢

    bounded NTK, i.e., ‚ÄñŒò‚Äño‚Å¢p=maxA‚Äñ‚àáŒ∏Tr‚Å¢[ZL‚Å¢AT]‚Äñ22‚ÄñA‚ÄñF2‚â§C‚Å¢L2subscriptnormŒòùëúùëùsubscriptmaxùê¥superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript‚àáùúÉTrdelimited-[]subscriptùëçùêøsuperscriptùê¥ùëá22superscriptsubscriptnormùê¥ùêπ2ùê∂subscriptùêø2\left\|\Theta\right\|_{op}=\mathop{\rm max}\nolimits_{A}\frac{\left\|\nabla_{% \theta}\mathrm{Tr}\left[Z_{L}A^{T}\right]\right\|_{2}^{2}}{\left\|A\right\|_{F% }^{2}}\leq CL_{2}‚à• roman_Œò ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG ‚à• ‚àá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ∏ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Tr [ italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ‚à• italic_A ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ‚â§ italic_C italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT,

  • ‚Ä¢

    approximate interpolation, i.e., ‚ÄñZL‚àíY‚ÄñF‚â§œµ1subscriptnormsubscriptùëçùêøùëåùêπsubscriptitalic-œµ1\left\|Z_{L}-Y\right\|_{F}\leq\epsilon_{1}‚à• italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Y ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â§ italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT,

  • ‚Ä¢

    bounded weights, i.e., ‚ÄñW‚Ñì‚Äño‚Å¢p‚â§rsubscriptnormsubscriptùëä‚Ñìùëúùëùùëü\left\|W_{\ell}\right\|_{op}\leq r‚à• italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â§ italic_r,

for any M‚â§L2ùëÄsubscriptùêø2M\leq L_{2}italic_M ‚â§ italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, there is ‚Ñì‚àà{L1+1,‚Ä¶,L1+M}‚Ñìsubscriptùêø11‚Ä¶subscriptùêø1ùëÄ\ell\in\{L_{1}+1,\dots,L_{1}+M\}roman_‚Ñì ‚àà { italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 , ‚Ä¶ , italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_M } such that Œ∫‚Å¢(WL:‚Ñì)‚â§C‚Å¢L2‚Å¢K‚Å¢rM‚Å¢(sK‚Å¢(Y)‚àíœµ1)ùúÖsubscriptùëä:ùêø‚Ñìùê∂subscriptùêø2ùêæùëüùëÄsubscriptùë†ùêæùëåsubscriptitalic-œµ1\kappa(W_{L:\ell})\leq\frac{\sqrt{CL_{2}}Kr}{\sqrt{M}\left(s_{K}(Y)-\epsilon_{% 1}\right)}italic_Œ∫ ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L : roman_‚Ñì end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ‚â§ divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_C italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG italic_K italic_r end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_M end_ARG ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Y ) - italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG.

Furthermore, any network that satisfies approximate interpolation and bounded weights is such that

‚ÄñŒò‚Äño‚Å¢p‚â•(sK‚Å¢(Y)‚àíœµ1)2K2‚Å¢r2‚Å¢L2.subscriptnormŒòùëúùëùsuperscriptsubscriptùë†ùêæùëåsubscriptitalic-œµ12superscriptùêæ2superscriptùëü2subscriptùêø2\left\|\Theta\right\|_{op}\geq\frac{\left(s_{K}(Y)-\epsilon_{1}\right)^{2}}{K^% {2}r^{2}}L_{2}.‚à• roman_Œò ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â• divide start_ARG ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Y ) - italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (20)

As an example, by choosing M=L22ùëÄsubscriptùêø22M=\frac{L_{2}}{2}italic_M = divide start_ARG italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG, we guarantee that there is at least one layer ‚Ñì‚Ñì\ellroman_‚Ñì in the first half of the linear layers s.t.  Œ∫‚Å¢(WL:‚Ñì)‚â§2‚Å¢C‚Å¢K‚Å¢rsK‚Å¢(Y)‚àíœµ1ùúÖsubscriptùëä:ùêø‚Ñì2ùê∂ùêæùëüsubscriptùë†ùêæùëåsubscriptitalic-œµ1\kappa(W_{L:\ell})\leq\frac{\sqrt{2C}Kr}{s_{K}(Y)-\epsilon_{1}}italic_Œ∫ ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L : roman_‚Ñì end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ‚â§ divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 italic_C end_ARG italic_K italic_r end_ARG start_ARG italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Y ) - italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG. Now, assuming the ‚Äòedge of stability‚Äô phenomenon, a learning rate of Œ∑=Œ∑0L2ùúÇsubscriptùúÇ0subscriptùêø2\eta=\frac{\eta_{0}}{L_{2}}italic_Œ∑ = divide start_ARG italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG implies a bound ‚ÄñŒò‚Äño‚Å¢p‚â§‚Äñ‚Ñã‚Å¢CŒª‚Äño‚Å¢p+O‚Å¢(œµ1)+O‚Å¢(Œª)‚â§2‚Å¢L2Œ∑0+O‚Å¢(œµ1)+O‚Å¢(Œª)subscriptnormŒòùëúùëùsubscriptnorm‚Ñãsubscriptùê∂ùúÜùëúùëùùëÇsubscriptitalic-œµ1ùëÇùúÜ2subscriptùêø2subscriptùúÇ0ùëÇsubscriptitalic-œµ1ùëÇùúÜ\left\|\Theta\right\|_{op}\leq\left\|\mathcal{H}C_{\lambda}\right\|_{op}+O(% \epsilon_{1})+O(\lambda)\leq\frac{2L_{2}}{\eta_{0}}+O(\epsilon_{1})+O(\lambda)‚à• roman_Œò ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â§ ‚à• caligraphic_H italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œª end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_O ( italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + italic_O ( italic_Œª ) ‚â§ divide start_ARG 2 italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG + italic_O ( italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + italic_O ( italic_Œª ), and thus Proposition 5.3 implies that there is a linear layer with bounded conditioning. Proposition 5.3 also suggests that one cannot take any significantly larger learning rate, since for any parameters that œµ1subscriptitalic-œµ1\epsilon_{1}italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-interpolate and have rùëüritalic_r-bounded weights, the NTK satisfies the lower bound in (20), which implies that the learning rate must be smaller than 2‚Å¢r2‚Å¢K2L2‚Å¢(sK‚Å¢(Y)‚àíœµ1)22superscriptùëü2superscriptùêæ2subscriptùêø2superscriptsubscriptùë†ùêæùëåsubscriptitalic-œµ12\frac{2r^{2}K^{2}}{L_{2}\left(s_{K}(Y)-\epsilon_{1}\right)^{2}}divide start_ARG 2 italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Y ) - italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG.

Proof sketch.

The idea is that, by suitably choosing Aùê¥Aitalic_A in the evaluation of ‚Äñ‚àáŒ∏Tr‚Å¢[ZL‚Å¢AT]‚Äñ22‚ÄñA‚ÄñF2superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript‚àáùúÉTrdelimited-[]subscriptùëçùêøsuperscriptùê¥ùëá22superscriptsubscriptnormùê¥ùêπ2\frac{\left\|\nabla_{\theta}\mathrm{Tr}\left[Z_{L}A^{T}\right]\right\|_{2}^{2}% }{\left\|A\right\|_{F}^{2}}divide start_ARG ‚à• ‚àá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ∏ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Tr [ italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ‚à• italic_A ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG, the operator norm of the NTK is lower bounded by some constant times ‚àë‚Ñì=L1+1LŒ∫‚Å¢(WL:‚Ñì)2superscriptsubscript‚Ñìsubscriptùêø11ùêøùúÖsuperscriptsubscriptùëä:ùêø‚Ñì2\sum_{\ell=L_{1}+1}^{L}\kappa(W_{L:\ell})^{2}‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì = italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œ∫ ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L : roman_‚Ñì end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. This implies the desired upper bound on Œ∫‚Å¢(WL:‚Ñì)ùúÖsubscriptùëä:ùêø‚Ñì\kappa(W_{L:\ell})italic_Œ∫ ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L : roman_‚Ñì end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) for some ‚Ñì‚àà{L1+1,‚Ä¶,L1+M}‚Ñìsubscriptùêø11‚Ä¶subscriptùêø1ùëÄ\ell\in\{L_{1}+1,\ldots,L_{1}+M\}roman_‚Ñì ‚àà { italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 , ‚Ä¶ , italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_M }, as well as the lower bound on ‚ÄñŒò‚Äño‚Å¢psubscriptnormŒòùëúùëù\|\Theta\|_{op}‚à• roman_Œò ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in (20). The details are deferred to Appendix B.

6 Numerical Results

In all experiments, we consider MSE loss and standard weight decay regularization. We train an MLP and a ResNet20 with an added MLP head on standard datasets (MNIST, CIFAR10), considering as backbone the first two layers for the MLP and the whole architecture before the linear head for the ResNet. We evaluate the following metrics related to neural collapse: for NC1, we compute tr‚Å¢(Œ£W)/tr‚Å¢(Œ£B),trsubscriptŒ£ùëätrsubscriptŒ£ùêµ\text{tr}(\Sigma_{W})/\text{tr}(\Sigma_{B}),tr ( roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / tr ( roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , where Œ£W,Œ£BsubscriptŒ£ùëäsubscriptŒ£ùêµ\Sigma_{W},\Sigma_{B}roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are the within- and between-class variability matrices of the feature matrices, respectively; for NC2, we display the conditioning number of the class-mean matrix; for NC3, we use the average cosine angle between the rows of a weight matrix and the columns of the preceding class-mean matrix. Finally, for balancedness we use ‚ÄñW‚Ñì+1‚ä§‚Å¢W‚Ñì+1‚àíW‚Ñì‚Å¢W‚Ñì‚ä§‚Äño‚Å¢pmin{‚ÄñW‚Ñì+1‚ä§‚Å¢W‚Ñì+1‚Äño‚Å¢p,‚ÄñW‚Ñì‚Å¢W‚Ñì‚ä§‚Äño‚Å¢p}subscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptùëä‚Ñì1topsubscriptùëä‚Ñì1subscriptùëä‚Ñìsuperscriptsubscriptùëä‚Ñìtopùëúùëùminsubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptùëä‚Ñì1topsubscriptùëä‚Ñì1ùëúùëùsubscriptnormsubscriptùëä‚Ñìsuperscriptsubscriptùëä‚Ñìtopùëúùëù\frac{\left\|W_{\ell+1}^{\top}W_{\ell+1}-W_{\ell}W_{\ell}^{\top}\right\|_{op}}% {\mathop{\rm min}\nolimits\left\{\left\|W_{\ell+1}^{\top}W_{\ell+1}\right\|_{% op},\left\|W_{\ell}W_{\ell}^{\top}\right\|_{op}\right\}}divide start_ARG ‚à• italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG roman_min { ‚à• italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚à• italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } end_ARG and for negativity we use ‚ÄñZ‚Ñì‚àíœÉ‚Å¢(Z‚Ñì)‚Äño‚Å¢p‚ÄñZ‚Ñì‚Äño‚Å¢p.subscriptnormsubscriptùëç‚Ñìùúésubscriptùëç‚Ñìùëúùëùsubscriptnormsubscriptùëç‚Ñìùëúùëù\frac{\left\|Z_{\ell}-\sigma(Z_{\ell})\right\|_{op}}{\left\|Z_{\ell}\right\|_{% op}}.divide start_ARG ‚à• italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_œÉ ( italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ‚à• italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG . We measure such metrics (and also index the layers) starting from the output of the backbone. Our findings can be summarized as follows (see Appendix A for additional complementary experiments).

The deeper the linear head, the more clear NC occurs.

We first test whether the models with deep linear heads exhibit NC and if that‚Äôs the case, whether it gets better as we deepen the linear head. In Figure 1, we show the NC metrics and the gram matrices of the class-mean matrices of the last layers for the training on CIFAR10 of ResNet20 with 6 extra layers of which the first three have a ReLU activation. We use weight decay of 0.0010.0010.0010.001 and learning rate of 0.0010.0010.0010.001, training for 5000 epochs (the learning rate drops ten-fold after 80% of the epochs in all our experiments).

The plot clearly shows that the collapse is reached throughout the training. We also see that the NC2 metric improves progressively with each layer of the linear head, as predicted by our theory. This effect is also clearly visible from the gram matrices of the class-means (bottom row of Figure 1), which rapidly converge towards the identity. We note that these findings are remarkably consistent across a wide variety of hyperparameter settings and architectures.

In Figure 2, we plot the dependence of the NC metrics on the number of layers in the linear head. We train an MLP on MNIST with 5 non-linear layers and a number of linear layers ranging from 1 to 5. We average over 5 runs per each combination of weight decay (0.001,0.0040.0010.0040.001,0.0040.001 , 0.004) and with learning rate of 0.0010.0010.0010.001. We also train the ResNet20 on CIFAR10 with one non-linear layer head and 1 to 6 linear layers on top. We use the same weight decay and learning rate. The relatively high variance of the results is due to averaging over rather strongly different weight decay values used per each depth. The plots clearly show that the NC2 significantly improves in the last layer as the depth of the linear head increases, while it gets slightly worse in the input layer to the linear head. This is consistent with our theory. The NC1 does not have a strong dependence with the number of layers.

Linear layers are increasingly balanced throughout training.

Figure 1 shows that the metric capturing the balancedness exponentially decreases until it plateaus at a rather small value (due to the large learning rate) and then again it exponentially decreases at a smaller rate after reducing the learning rate. The balancedness of non-linear layers instead plateaus at a significantly larger value.

Non-linear layers are increasingly balanced and linear, as the depth of the non-linear part increases.

In Figure 3, we show the dependence of balancedness and non-linearity of the non-linear layers as a function of the depth of the non-linear part. In particular, we plot minimum balancedness and non-linearity across all layers, as well as mean balancedness and non-linearity. The depth of the non-linear part ranges from 4 to 12 (the first two layers are considered as backbone and not measured), the learning rate is either 0.0010.0010.0010.001 or 0.0020.0020.0020.002 (5 runs each), and the weight decay is 0.0160.0160.0160.016 divided by the total number of layers. Balancedness clearly improves with depth, both on average per layer and in the most balanced layer. Similarly, the non-negativity of the layer that least uses the ReLU clearly decreases, and a decrease in the mean negativity is also reported (although less pronounced). Thus, these results suggest that the network tends to use non-linearities less as the depth increases and, in addition, it becomes more balanced. We also note that, in order to fit the data, regardless of the depth, the last non-linear layer(s) always exhibit significant negativity, heavily relying on the ReLU.

Neither the European Union nor the granting authority can be held responsible for them.

  • Tirer et al. (2023) Tom Tirer, Haoxiang Huang, and Jonathan Niles-Weed. Perturbation analysis of neural collapse. In International Conference on Machine Learning (ICML), 2023.
  • Tu et al. (2024) Zhenfeng Tu, Santiago Aranguri, and Arthur Jacot. Mixed dynamics in linear networks: Unifying the lazy and active regimes. arXiv preprint arXiv:2405.17580, 2024.
  • Wang et al. (2022) Peng Wang, Huikang Liu, Can Yaras, Laura Balzano, and Qing Qu. Linear convergence analysis of neural collapse with unconstrained features. In NeurIPS Workshop on Optimization for Machine Learning (OPT), 2022.
  • Wang et al. (2024) Sicong Wang, Kuo Gai, and Shihua Zhang. Progressive feedforward collapse of resnet training. arXiv preprint arXiv:2405.00985, 2024.
  • Wang & Jacot (2024) Zihan Wang and Arthur Jacot. Implicit bias of SGD in L2subscriptùêø2L_{2}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-regularized linear DNNs: One-way jumps from high to low rank. In International Conference on Learning Representations (ICLR), 2024.
  • Wen & Jacot (2024) Yuxiao Wen and Arthur Jacot. Which frequencies do CNNs need? Emergent bottleneck structure in feature learning. arXiv preprint arXiv:2402.08010, 2024.
  • Xu et al. (2023) Mengjia Xu, Akshay Rangamani, Qianli Liao, Tomer Galanti, and Tomaso Poggio. Dynamics in deep classifiers trained with the square loss: Normalization, low rank, neural collapse, and generalization bounds. In Research, volume 6, 2023.
  • Zangrando et al. (2024) Emanuele Zangrando, Piero Deidda, Simone Brugiapaglia, Nicola Guglielmi, and Francesco Tudisco. Neural rank collapse: Weight decay and small within-class variability yield low-rank bias. arXiv preprint arXiv:2402.03991, 2024.
  • Zhang et al. (2024) Jiawei Zhang, Yufan Chen, Cheng Jin, Lei Zhu, and Yuantao Gu. EPA: neural collapse inspired robust out-of-distribution detector. arXiv preprint arXiv:2401.01710, 2024.
  • Zhou et al. (2022a) Jinxin Zhou, Xiao Li, Tianyu Ding, Chong You, Qing Qu, and Zhihui Zhu. On the optimization landscape of neural collapse under MSE loss: Global optimality with unconstrained features. In International Conference on Machine Learning (ICML), 2022a.
  • Zhou et al. (2022b) Jinxin Zhou, Chong You, Xiao Li, Kangning Liu, Sheng Liu, Qing Qu, and Zhihui Zhu. Are all losses created equal: A neural collapse perspective. In Advances in Neural Information Processing Systems (NeurIPS), 2022b.
  • Zhu et al. (2021) Zhihui Zhu, Tianyu Ding, Jinxin Zhou, Xiao Li, Chong You, Jeremias Sulam, and Qing Qu. A geometric analysis of neural collapse with unconstrained features. In Advances in Neural Information Processing Systems (NeurIPS), 2021.
  • Zou & Gu (2019) Difan Zou and Quanquan Gu. An improved analysis of training over-parameterized deep neural networks. In Advances in Neural Information Processing Systems (NeurIPS), 2019.

Appendix A Additional Experiments

We complement the experiments from Section 6 with additional numerical findings. We start by showing an analog of Figure 1 for MLP trained on MNIST to show that the behavior is robust with respect to the backbone and dataset. The results are shown in Figure 4. The architecture is an MLP with 5 non-linear layers followed by 4 linear layers. We use weight decay of 0.00180.00180.00180.0018 and learning rate of 0.0010.0010.0010.001, training for 10000 epochs.

The plot fully agrees with the one in Figure 1 with ResNet20 training on CIFAR10 in every qualitative aspect, and it only differs in the numerical values attained by the NC metrics. Therefore, the conclusion is that the NC is attained across different architectures and NC2 progressively improves as we get closer to the last layer of the DNN.

Next, we extend Figure 2 with experiments on ResNet20 trained on MNIST, which are shown in Figure 5. As above, the results match the interpretations discussed in Section 6, which proves the robustness of our findings across different achitectures, datasets and hyperparameter settings.

Appendix B Deferred Proofs

See 3.1

Proof.

NC1: We start by proving the claim (2) on NC1. We have

(21)

Putting these together, we have:

‚à•ZL‚àí1‚àíWL+‚Å¢Y‚à•F‚â§r‚Å¢(œµ1sK‚Å¢(Y)‚àíœµ1+nL‚àí1‚Å¢œµ2)=Œ®‚Å¢(œµ1,œµ2,r).subscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùëçùêø1superscriptsubscriptùëäùêøùëåùêπùëüsubscriptitalic-œµ1subscriptùë†ùêæùëåsubscriptitalic-œµ1subscriptùëõùêø1subscriptitalic-œµ2Œ®subscriptitalic-œµ1subscriptitalic-œµ2ùëü\left\lVert Z_{L-1}-W_{L}^{+}Y\right\rVert_{F}\leq r\left(\frac{\epsilon_{1}}{% s_{K}(Y)-\epsilon_{1}}+\sqrt{n_{L-1}\epsilon_{2}}\right)=\Psi(\epsilon_{1},% \epsilon_{2},r).‚à• italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â§ italic_r ( divide start_ARG italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Y ) - italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG + square-root start_ARG italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) = roman_Œ® ( italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_r ) . (22)

From now on, we will drop the index L‚àí1ùêø1L-1italic_L - 1 and treat everything without layer label as belonging to that layer (the membership to any other layer will be indexed). We have that

‚â§1N‚Å¢‚àëc,i‚Äñzc‚Å¢i‚àí(WL+)c:‚Äñ22=1N‚Å¢‚ÄñZL‚àí1‚àíWL+‚Å¢Y‚ÄñF2.absent1ùëÅsubscriptùëêùëñsuperscriptsubscriptnormsubscriptùëßùëêùëñsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptùëäùêø:ùëêabsent221ùëÅsubscriptsuperscriptnormsubscriptùëçùêø1superscriptsubscriptùëäùêøùëå2ùêπ\displaystyle\leq\frac{1}{N}\sum_{c,i}\left\|z_{ci}-(W_{L}^{+})_{c:}\right\|_{% 2}^{2}=\frac{1}{N}\left\|Z_{L-1}-W_{L}^{+}Y\right\|^{2}_{F}.‚â§ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_N end_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c : end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_N end_ARG ‚à• italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

Furthermore,

tr‚Å¢(Œ£B)trsubscriptŒ£ùêµ\displaystyle\text{tr}(\Sigma_{B})tr ( roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) =tr‚Å¢(1K‚Å¢‚àëc=1K(Œºc‚àíŒºG)‚Å¢(Œºc‚àíŒºG)‚ä§)=1K‚Å¢‚àëc=1K‚ÄñŒºc‚àíŒºG‚Äñ22absenttr1ùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùëê1ùêæsubscriptùúáùëêsubscriptùúáùê∫superscriptsubscriptùúáùëêsubscriptùúáùê∫top1ùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùëê1ùêæsuperscriptsubscriptnormsubscriptùúáùëêsubscriptùúáùê∫22\displaystyle=\text{tr}\left(\frac{1}{K}\sum_{c=1}^{K}(\mu_{c}-\mu_{G})(\mu_{c% }-\mu_{G})^{\top}\right)=\frac{1}{K}\sum_{c=1}^{K}\left\|\mu_{c}-\mu_{G}\right% \|_{2}^{2}= tr ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ( italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT
‚â•‚ÄñWL‚Äño‚Å¢p2r2‚Å¢1K‚Å¢‚àëc=1K‚ÄñŒºc‚àíŒºG‚Äñ22‚â•1K‚Å¢r2‚Å¢‚àëc=1K‚ÄñŒºcL‚àíŒºGL‚Äñ22.absentsubscriptsuperscriptnormsubscriptùëäùêø2ùëúùëùsuperscriptùëü21ùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùëê1ùêæsuperscriptsubscriptnormsubscriptùúáùëêsubscriptùúáùê∫221ùêæsuperscriptùëü2superscriptsubscriptùëê1ùêæsuperscriptsubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptùúáùëêùêøsuperscriptsubscriptùúáùê∫ùêø22\displaystyle\geq\frac{\left\|W_{L}\right\|^{2}_{op}}{r^{2}}\frac{1}{K}\sum_{c% =1}^{K}\left\|\mu_{c}-\mu_{G}\right\|_{2}^{2}\geq\frac{1}{Kr^{2}}\sum_{c=1}^{K% }\left\|\mu_{c}^{L}-\mu_{G}^{L}\right\|_{2}^{2}.‚â• divide start_ARG ‚à• italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚â• divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_K italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

Now we proceed by lower-bounding the last term:

1K‚Å¢‚àëc=1K‚ÄñŒºcL‚àíŒºGL‚Äñ221ùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùëê1ùêæsuperscriptsubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptùúáùëêùêøsuperscriptsubscriptùúáùê∫ùêø22\displaystyle\frac{1}{K}\sum_{c=1}^{K}\left\|\mu_{c}^{L}-\mu_{G}^{L}\right\|_{% 2}^{2}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚â•(1K‚Å¢‚àëc=1K‚ÄñŒºcL‚àíŒºGL‚Äñ2)2absentsuperscript1ùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùëê1ùêæsubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptùúáùëêùêøsuperscriptsubscriptùúáùê∫ùêø22\displaystyle\geq\left(\frac{1}{K}\sum_{c=1}^{K}\left\|\mu_{c}^{L}-\mu_{G}^{L}% \right\|_{2}\right)^{2}‚â• ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT

Next we have:

‚ÄñŒºGY‚àíŒºGL‚Äñ2subscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptùúáùê∫ùëåsuperscriptsubscriptùúáùê∫ùêø2\displaystyle\left\|\mu_{G}^{Y}-\mu_{G}^{L}\right\|_{2}‚à• italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =‚Äñ1N‚Å¢‚àëc,izc‚Å¢iL‚àí1N‚Å¢‚àëc,izc‚Å¢iY‚Äñ2‚â§1N‚Å¢‚àëc,i‚Äñzc‚Å¢iL‚àízc‚Å¢iY‚Äñ2absentsubscriptnorm1ùëÅsubscriptùëêùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùëßùëêùëñùêø1ùëÅsubscriptùëêùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùëßùëêùëñùëå21ùëÅsubscriptùëêùëñsubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptùëßùëêùëñùêøsuperscriptsubscriptùëßùëêùëñùëå2\displaystyle=\left\|\frac{1}{N}\sum_{c,i}z_{ci}^{L}-\frac{1}{N}\sum_{c,i}z_{% ci}^{Y}\right\|_{2}\leq\frac{1}{N}\sum_{c,i}\left\|z_{ci}^{L}-z_{ci}^{Y}\right% \|_{2}= ‚à• divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_N end_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_N end_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â§ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_N end_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
‚â§1N‚Å¢‚àëc,i‚Äñzc‚Å¢iL‚àízc‚Å¢iY‚Äñ22=1N‚Å¢‚ÄñZL‚àíY‚ÄñF‚â§œµ1N.absent1ùëÅsubscriptùëêùëñsuperscriptsubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptùëßùëêùëñùêøsuperscriptsubscriptùëßùëêùëñùëå221ùëÅsubscriptnormsubscriptùëçùêøùëåùêπsubscriptitalic-œµ1ùëÅ\displaystyle\leq\sqrt{\frac{1}{N}\sum_{c,i}\left\|z_{ci}^{L}-z_{ci}^{Y}\right% \|_{2}^{2}}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}\left\|Z_{L}-Y\right\|_{F}\leq\frac{\epsilon_{1}% }{\sqrt{N}}.‚â§ square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_N end_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_N end_ARG end_ARG ‚à• italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Y ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â§ divide start_ARG italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_N end_ARG end_ARG .

Finally, for any fixed cùëêcitalic_c we have

‚ÄñŒºcY‚àíŒºcL‚Äñ2=‚Äñ1n‚Å¢‚àëizc‚Å¢iY‚àí1n‚Å¢‚àëizc‚Å¢iL‚Äñ2‚â§1n‚Å¢‚àëi‚Äñzc‚Å¢iY‚àízc‚Å¢iL‚Äñ2.subscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptùúáùëêùëåsuperscriptsubscriptùúáùëêùêø2subscriptnorm1ùëõsubscriptùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùëßùëêùëñùëå1ùëõsubscriptùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùëßùëêùëñùêø21ùëõsubscriptùëñsubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptùëßùëêùëñùëåsuperscriptsubscriptùëßùëêùëñùêø2\displaystyle\left\|\mu_{c}^{Y}-\mu_{c}^{L}\right\|_{2}=\left\|\frac{1}{n}\sum% _{i}z_{ci}^{Y}-\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i}z_{ci}^{L}\right\|_{2}\leq\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i% }\left\|z_{ci}^{Y}-z_{ci}^{L}\right\|_{2}.‚à• italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ‚à• divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â§ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

Therefore we get:

1K‚Å¢‚àëc=1K‚ÄñŒºcY‚àíŒºcL‚Äñ2‚â§1N‚Å¢‚àëc,i‚Äñzc‚Å¢iY‚àízc‚Å¢iL‚Äñ2‚â§1N‚Å¢‚ÄñZL‚àíY‚ÄñF‚â§œµ1N.1ùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùëê1ùêæsubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptùúáùëêùëåsuperscriptsubscriptùúáùëêùêø21ùëÅsubscriptùëêùëñsubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptùëßùëêùëñùëåsuperscriptsubscriptùëßùëêùëñùêø21ùëÅsubscriptnormsubscriptùëçùêøùëåùêπsubscriptitalic-œµ1ùëÅ\displaystyle\frac{1}{K}\sum_{c=1}^{K}\left\|\mu_{c}^{Y}-\mu_{c}^{L}\right\|_{% 2}\leq\frac{1}{N}\sum_{c,i}\left\|z_{ci}^{Y}-z_{ci}^{L}\right\|_{2}\leq\frac{1% }{\sqrt{N}}\left\|Z_{L}-Y\right\|_{F}\leq\frac{\epsilon_{1}}{\sqrt{N}}.divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â§ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_N end_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â§ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_N end_ARG end_ARG ‚à• italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Y ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â§ divide start_ARG italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_N end_ARG end_ARG .

Upper bounding these terms in the above computation and dividing tr‚Å¢(Œ£W)trsubscriptŒ£ùëä\text{tr}(\Sigma_{W})tr ( roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) by tr‚Å¢(Œ£B)trsubscriptŒ£ùêµ\text{tr}(\Sigma_{B})tr ( roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) yields (2).

Conditioning of WLsubscriptùëäùêøW_{L}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT: We now prove the claim (3) on the conditioning of WLsubscriptùëäùêøW_{L}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We rely first on Lemma C.2 to relate the singular values of WLsubscriptùëäùêøW_{L}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to the L2subscriptùêø2L_{2}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-th root of those of WL:L1+1subscriptùëä:ùêøsubscriptùêø11W_{L:L_{1}+1}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L : italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We therefore obtain that

s1‚Å¢(WL)2‚Å¢L2sK‚Å¢(WL)2‚Å¢L2subscriptùë†1superscriptsubscriptùëäùêø2subscriptùêø2subscriptùë†ùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùëäùêø2subscriptùêø2\displaystyle\frac{s_{1}(W_{L})^{2L_{2}}}{s_{K}(W_{L})^{2L_{2}}}divide start_ARG italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ‚â§s1‚Å¢(WL:L1+1)2+L222‚Å¢r2‚Å¢(L2‚àí1)‚Å¢œµ2sK‚Å¢(WL:L1+1)2‚àíL222‚Å¢r2‚Å¢(L2‚àí1)‚Å¢œµ2absentsubscriptùë†1superscriptsubscriptùëä:ùêøsubscriptùêø112superscriptsubscriptùêø222superscriptùëü2subscriptùêø21subscriptitalic-œµ2subscriptùë†ùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùëä:ùêøsubscriptùêø112superscriptsubscriptùêø222superscriptùëü2subscriptùêø21subscriptitalic-œµ2\displaystyle\leq\frac{s_{1}(W_{L:L_{1}+1})^{2}+\frac{L_{2}^{2}}{2}r^{2(L_{2}-% 1)}\epsilon_{2}}{s_{K}(W_{L:L_{1}+1})^{2}-\frac{L_{2}^{2}}{2}r^{2(L_{2}-1)}% \epsilon_{2}}‚â§ divide start_ARG italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L : italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + divide start_ARG italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 ( italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L : italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - Thus, the following chain of inequalities gives (3):

using the concavity of the 2‚Å¢L22subscriptùêø22L_{2}2 italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-th root.

NC(2+3): We start with the proof of the claim (5) on NC3, as the derivations will be used in the proof of the claim (4) on NC2 later. Since the cosine similarity does not depend on the scale of the involved matrices, we perform the following rescaling: denoting Œ±=‚ÄñWL‚Äñùõºnormsubscriptùëäùêø\alpha=\left\|W_{L}\right\|italic_Œ± = ‚à• italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à•, we define WL‚Ä≤=WLŒ±superscriptsubscriptùëäùêø‚Ä≤subscriptùëäùêøùõºW_{L}^{\prime}=\frac{W_{L}}{\alpha}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = divide start_ARG italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_Œ± end_ARG and ZL‚àí1‚Ä≤=Œ±‚Å¢ZL‚àí1.superscriptsubscriptùëçùêø1‚Ä≤ùõºsubscriptùëçùêø1Z_{L-1}^{\prime}=\alpha Z_{L-1}.italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_Œ± italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . Similarly to before we denote (z‚Ä≤)c‚Å¢i(L‚àí1)subscriptsuperscriptsuperscriptùëß‚Ä≤ùêø1ùëêùëñ(z^{\prime})^{(L-1)}_{ci}( italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_L - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT the iùëñiitalic_i-th sample of the cùëêcitalic_c-th class in the matrix ZL‚àí1‚Ä≤.superscriptsubscriptùëçùêø1‚Ä≤Z_{L-1}^{\prime}.italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . Then, we write

NC3‚Å¢(ZL‚àí1‚Ä≤,WL‚Ä≤)NC3superscriptsubscriptùëçùêø1‚Ä≤superscriptsubscriptùëäùêø‚Ä≤\displaystyle\text{NC3}(Z_{L-1}^{\prime},W_{L}^{\prime})NC3 ( italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) =1N‚Å¢‚àëc,icos‚Å°((z‚Ä≤)c‚Å¢i(L‚àí1),(WL‚Ä≤)c:)=1N‚Å¢‚àëc,i‚ü®(z‚Ä≤)c‚Å¢i(L‚àí1),(WL‚Ä≤)c:‚ü©‚Äñ(z‚Ä≤)c‚Å¢i(L‚àí1)‚Äñ2‚Å¢‚Äñ(WL‚Ä≤)c:‚Äñ2absent1ùëÅsubscriptùëêùëñsubscriptsuperscriptsuperscriptùëß‚Ä≤ùêø1ùëêùëñsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptùëäùêø‚Ä≤:ùëêabsent1ùëÅsubscriptùëêùëñsubscriptsuperscriptsuperscriptùëß‚Ä≤ùêø1ùëêùëñsubscriptsubscriptsuperscriptùëä‚Ä≤ùêø:ùëêabsentsubscriptnormsubscriptsuperscriptsuperscriptùëß‚Ä≤ùêø1ùëêùëñ2subscriptnormsubscriptsubscriptsuperscriptùëä‚Ä≤ùêø:ùëêabsent2\displaystyle=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{c,i}\cos((z^{\prime})^{(L-1)}_{ci},(W_{L}^{% \prime})_{c:})=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{c,i}\frac{\left\langle(z^{\prime})^{(L-1)}_{ci% },(W^{\prime}_{L})_{c:}\right\rangle}{\left\|(z^{\prime})^{(L-1)}_{ci}\right\|% _{2}\left\|(W^{\prime}_{L})_{c:}\right\|_{2}}= divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_N end_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cos ( ( italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_L - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c : end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_N end_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG ‚ü® ( italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_L - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ( italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c : end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ü© end_ARG start_ARG ‚à• ( italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_L -
